body:
Having been excited about Ruby on Rails since just after its 1.0 release back in late 2005, it’s hard to imagine life without it. Whenever I come across a tangled knot of PHP or a Java beast my first response is “I wish this was Rails.” But by around 2010 there arose a potential challenger:

Node.js

When I first understood the benefits of asynchronous, event-driven flow I was really excited. It made perfect sense with analogies like the fast food restaurant. So I got Node running and my first impression was “wow, this is so much faster than Rails; I need to think about refactoring all my apps into Node”. But it didn’t take long to realize that wasn’t going to work. Node.js was missing lots of the things I took for granted with Rails. Things like form helpers and MVC architecture. Now I’m sure lots of people can respond with “Node’s got those–look at X, Y and Z!” I’ve tried Express and even Railway. None of them seemed to just get things right the way Rails does. Rails is opinionated software that makes a lot of choices from the start. Not all of those choices are going to be correct, but there’s nearly always a way to change the defaults. Moreover, all other things being equal, I’m on the side of DHH on preferring to code in Ruby over Javascript.

Drawbacks to Rails

Rails is getting faster and more powerful all the time, but it’s start up time is still quite slow. Its response time would benefit greatly if it used an asynchronous, event driven architecture, but that would require rewriting the entire framework and all its libraries–never a good idea. You’d lose all the synchronous advantages like simplicity of code, no need for callbacks, sequential execution, and ease of debugging.

Faye to the Rescue

So how can we have our cake and eat it? Faye uses the powerful EventMachine library to bring event processing to Ruby. It wasn’t hard to integrate with Ruby, especially thanks to Ryan Bates’ handy PrivatePub (Railscast). So now we have both synchronous and asynchronous I/O living in the same app. How does this help? Forms and views can be written in the standard Rails way and server push notifications can be sent out at any time. Client events can trigger Rails actions that notify other clients of the changes à la NowJS.

Other Options

Other than Rails and Node, there are a few notable frameworks in other languages. Erlang is a good language choice because of its concurrency and making asynchronous development easier. Chicago Boss and Nitrogen both look like promising frameworks written in Erlang. Haskel enforces strict typing and automatically executes in a non-blocking manner and boasts the Yesod web framework. Choosing these or other less mainstream languages may or may not pan out well depending on your organization’s willingness to try new things.

The Future

So what will the next generation of web frameworks be like? I don’t see a clear winner here. Rails is excellent at building RESTful services and Node works great for client-heavy web apps. Rails’ features will gradually get ported over to Node through packages such as Express and Railway. Node will influence Rails developers to consider event-driven architecture where they need it, such as push notifications and multi-user collaboration. Other languages will exert their influence and perhaps produce formidable challengers to Rails and Node. From a user’s perspective a non-blocking asynchronous application seems faster as the UI can continue to accept input even while performing tasks on the server. So I do hope to see more emphasis in the Rails community on event-driven I/O.

body:
There are tons of articles online about the benefits of Test Driven Development, people who love it, people who “ain’t got time for that”, and people who don’t get it. I’m new to programming and I had the luxury of learning to program by letting tests drive my development. This post is about learning TDD as a beginner.

Three weeks into my Ruby on Rails training I was bombarded with TDD. Initially overwhelmed, I wrote it off as another set of syntax to learn with no real benefits. What’s the point right? I’ll know if my code doesn’t work because, well...it won’t work. I was required to use TDD in the beginning of my training and the more I used it, the more I understood and appreciated the benefits.

Maintaining focus. You have a problem, you start to solve it, and before you know it you’re working on a totally different issue. How do you know what you want to happen or when the problem is solved? What do you want out of the code? The tests will tell you! These questions are the first ones you answer while writing your tests. It forces you to plan first then write the code to make it do what you want later. Baby steps is the name of the game when incrementally building solid code functionality. Write the tests that fail, do the simplest thing that works, and then move on to the next. Programming this way really lets you focus on the creative part of the problem solving rather than getting caught up in trying to remember what you were doing. TDD works as an outline to keep you focused and in your flow.

The consumer of the software we build matters, right? When you write tests you write them around exactly how the consumer will use the software, what you want them to experience, and what you want to happen. The first thing you have to do is think about each step the consumer will take. If you write strong tests, your code will be more solid, concise, and do what you want it to do.

The greatest gift TDD ever gave me was a deeper understanding of the MVC pattern, which was a difficult concept for me to grasp as a new programmer; especially figuring out how they all work together and what each one is in charge of, I’m still learning! It’s all part of the RED, GREEN, REFACTOR mantra. When you write tests, you write them so that they will fail. That failure will give you an error with clues about where in the program the problem is taking place. Is it telling you it can’t find the ‘Submit’ button? Well then you know you probably want to check the view to see if you have it there. It gives you a starting point to solve the problem, an immensely beneficial aspect when trying to fix a broken program.

New to TDD? Here are a couple resources:

  • Ryan Bates’ Railscast, “How I Test”
  • Thoughtbot’s RSpec Matchers Cheatsheet

What is your experience with TDD? Comment below to let us know your thoughts or if you have any questions!

body:
The relationship between humans and computers is largely one-sided, meaning that we use computers and not the other way around. The paradigm looks like this:

As software developers, it’s our job to write programs that turn inputs into outputs. We do this by writing algorithms. You can think of an algorithm like a recipe. For example, the algorithm for “outputting” a peanut butter and jelly sandwich works like this:

PB&J Algorithm:
  1. Get two slices of bread (input)
  2. Get some peanut butter (input)
  3. Get some jelly (input)
  4. Get a knife (input)
  5. Use the knife to get some peanut butter and spread it onto one of the slices of bread
  6. Use the knife to get some jelly and spread it on the other piece of bread
  7. Take the piece of bread with jelly on it and put it on top of the piece of bread with peanut butter (with the jelly side touching the peanut butter side)

Easy, right?

Let’s try something a little more difficult. In the next example we’re going to output a temperature in degrees Fahrenheit from an input measured in degrees Celsius

Fahrenheit to Celsius Algorithm:
  1. Get a temperature in degrees Celsius
  2. Subtract 32 from the temperature
  3. Multiply the temperature by 5/9

It turns out that computers are really good at following instructions. That’s why computers are so great at doing things like:

  • Storing information
  • Displaying information
  • Finding “needles in haystacks”

But what if we were to say, “Computer, is this a good haircut?”

Human-based Computation for Haircuts

Well as it turns out, there are a handful of approaches that we could use to solve this. We’ll cover a few examples of how we could make a recipe to solve the problem.

The Classical Approach

The first problem that you might notice is that a “good haircut” is difficult to quantify. But if we put our mind to it, we might come up with a list of quantifiable traits that looks something like this:

  • Hair color
  • Distribution of colors
  • Tightness of edges
  • Evenness
  • Symmetry
  • Amount of split-ends
  • Smoothness of fit to shape of the head

We could then write an algorithm that looks like this:

  1. Get a picture of the haircut (i.e., convert the haircut into machine language)
  2. Analyze the pixels
  3. Quantify all traits as a function of those pixels
  4. Calculate a score based on how well the picture meets those traits

It may come as no surprise to you that this would be an incredibly difficult algorithm to program, and its accuracy would vary tremendously. As it turns out, computers are not very good at these kinds of tasks, so we scrap this approach and all of its second-cousins.

The Deterministic Approach

Let’s assume for a second that we have unlimited time and resources. How would we solve the problem then?

We could use an algorithm like this:

  1. Ask everyone on Earth whether or not they like the haircut
  2. Record their answers as either 1’s (yes), 0’s (don’t know) or -1’s (no)
  3. Add all the responses together
  4. If the result of this summation is > 0, it’s a good haircut
  5. Otherwise, it’s a bad haircut

In theory, this algorithm would always return the same result (like our Fahrenheit to Celsius algorithm). But in practice, this algorithm doesn’t work because we don’t have unlimited time and resources.

A Probabilistic Approach

OK, so this is where the fun begins. Let’s assume that you just got a haircut. You’re not sure what you think of it. But you paid $20, so you’d like to find out whether it is good or not. How would you do it?

If you’re like me, you’d start by asking, “Mom, do you like my haircut?” which she would answer with a resounding yes. But just to make sure, you ask someone else and log your results as follows:

Person Name

Answer

Now what?

My Mom

Yes

Ask someone else

My boss

Yes

Ask someone else

Steve

No

Ask someone else

Ben

No

Ask someone else

Brittany

No

Ask someone else

Eric

No

Ask someone else

Dante

Yes

Ask someone else

Cecilia

No

Ask someone else

Peter

No

Ask someone else

Paulie

No

Ask someone else

Dalai Lama

No

Get a new haircut

One can also imagine a scenario that might looks like this:

Person Name

Answer

Now What?

Hootie

Yes

Ask someone else

Bryan

Yes

Ask someone else

Billy

No

Ask someone else

Bobby

Yes

Ask someone else

Mike

Yes

Ask someone else

Jerry

Yes

Stop asking; it’s good

The algorithm for this approach works like this:

  1. Ask someone new
  2. Record their answer
  3. Repeat Step 1 and 2 unless we’re pretty sure it’s either good or bad based on:
    • Who we’ve asked
    • How much they know about haircuts
    • How much they like my other haircuts
    • How they’ve collectively answered

The savvy reader may have noticed the phrase “unless we’re pretty sure” in the algorithm. This is called a probabilistic algorithm. Unlike the deterministic approach (where we ask everyone), this algorithm may return different results based on who we ask (and in what order we ask them). This is how your brain works. It turns perceptions (inputs) into experiences (outputs), where past experiences affect current perception.

This human-based, human-inspired, discrete probabilistic approach is the most accurate and efficient way to solve a consensus task.

In a consensus task, the goal is to identify a hidden state of the world by collecting multiple assessments from human workers. (In our example, whether the haircut is good or bad.)

In order to solve consensus tasks eﬀectively, the decision making system needs to trade oﬀ the benefit of asking someone new with its immediate cost (in our example, the time and efforts spent asking). Here’s how it works:

This algorithm can then be generalized to work for any consensus task, which means that with the help of humans, computers can solve even the most elusive computations, leaving only the matter of economics.

The Matter of Finding Human Help

In the generalized model of the algorithm, we calculate the marginal utility of hiring another worker (i.e, asking another friend). If the marginal cost of getting another answer outweighs the marginal utility of getting another answer, we terminate the loop and accept our current perception as true.

We could then use this calculation to create a market with Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, which has no minimum wage laws:

Pooling judgments across all 7 (image labeling) tasks we ﬁnd that on average it requires only 4 non-expert annotations per example to achieve the equivalent ITA as a single expert annotator. Given that we paid US $2.00 in order to collect the 7000 non-expert annotations, we may interpret our rate of 3500 non-expert labels per USD as at least 875 expert-equivalent labels per USD.
— http://www.stanford.edu/~jurafsky/amt.pdf

And while bypassing minimum wage is cool, what’s cooler is to bypass wage entirely.

Luis von Ahn, inventor of reCAPTCHA, Games With A Purpose, and Duolingo — and father of Human Computation — has mastered the art of free labor. If you’re interested in hearing more about motivating a workforce, I invite you to check out this talk:

Luis von Ahn on Games With A Purpose

Applications of Human Computation

At its core — human computation is a way of taking what our brains do really well, and combining, storing, and synthesizing that information to ultimately output a bigger light bulb.

Cool. So let’s consider a few practical applications.

Galaxy Zoo

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey used advances in imaging technology to collect pictures of millions of galaxies. The end result of the survey was a data set bigger than anything we had ever collected. Now imagine you’re a graduate student in astronomy. As part of your PhD, you are put to the task of classifying as much of the collected data as possible. (Someone’s got to do it and machines aren’t accurate enough). If you don’t sleep, you might be able to classify 10,000 galaxies per year. If we assume that there are one million objects to be classified, this would equate to 100 PhD man-years.

GalaxyZoo is a project that set out to solve this problem. The premise is simple. They ask regular folks like you and me to classify galaxies into either ellipses or spirals. With so many galaxies, you might expect that it would take years for visitors of the site to work through them all, but within 24 hours of launch they were receiving almost 70,000 classifications per hour. By the end of it’s first year, more than 50 million classifications were received, contributed by more than 150,000 people. That means that each galaxy was seen by ~50 participants. And since one expert can be replaced by a number of non-experts, they were able to increase the level of accuracy in a fraction of the time.

reCAPTCHA

Have you ever seen these squiggly characters when you fill out a form online?

reCAPTCHA is actually a way of using human computation to teach computers how to read while providing security against spammers. Here’s how it works:

But why two words? Well the computer is relatively certain that it knows the word “upon”, and the word “between” is unknown.  Thus, we have a consensus task of revealing what the word that we recognize as “between” actually is (e.g., good or bad haircut?). If enough people agree that the word is “between” the program stops asking and assumes that the word is, in fact, “between”.

Because so many people use reCAPTCHA (i.e., Facebook, Twitter, etc.) — the program was able to translate the entire New York Times archive in a few months — (less than) one word at a time.

Our Clients

Dognition: Artificial Canine Intelligence

Can you name this man?

If you said BF Skinner, give yourself a repeated slap in the face.

Skinner was psychology’s original pessimist. He believed that behavior was simply a matter of stimulus and response. And that by modifying the consequence of a behavior, it could be eliminated entirely.

Skinner popularized a school of thought called Behaviorism, which took its roots in the work of men like Pavlov, Darwin and Freud. The paradigm for behaviorism looks like this:

Skinner used this model to argue that freedom was neither real nor necessary. And so did his followers.

Now give yourself 939 points if you can name this man:

This is Noam Chomsky, the most frequently cited academic on Earth, conqueror of behaviorism, and champion of freedom. What was foundational about Chomsky’s early work on Linguistics was a flaw in Skinner’s model:

Dr. Brian Hare, founder of Dognition, realized that what was true for humans must also be true for dogs. We helped him and his team create Dognition as a way for people to find out more about their dogs, while giving researchers insights into how the algorithms inside different dog’s minds work. At its core, Dognition is a series of psychological tests and interactive games that allows us to evaluate each dog across a spectrum of cognitive characteristics. We can then combine this data and use machine learning to reveal insights into previously hidden states of canine intelligence — very much like asking, “Computer, what are these dogs thinking?”

Naturally, humans have better algorithms for processing information than dogs. It’s the reason that we hold the leash. At Smashing Boxes, we’re focused on finding the best ways to turn inputs into outputs through our custom applications. Sometimes that involves making a Rails app. Sometimes it involves mobile. And sometimes, we just ask people what they think.

We are entrepreneurs and craftsmen first, and a digital creative agency second. Inspired by our visionary clients, we transform ideas into innovative web and mobile applications. Take a look at our work.

  • Arfon Smith for showing me Crowdsynth

  • Carnegie Mellon University for making math cool
  • Wikipedia for the pictures of Skinner and Chomsky

body:
In this third and final part of my "Merging ember-cli with Rails" blog series, I will talk about how I connected the Ember frontend with the Rails backend so that beer rankings could be persisted in the database.

Writing the AJAX call.

In Part 2 you may recall the swap controller action I put in my ballot controller. Well, that wasn't sending anything back to the Rails API. Every time I reloaded the browser, my beers were back in their original order. Let’s fix that.

EmberApp/app/controllers/ballot.js

import Ember from 'ember';

export default Ember.Controller.extend({
  sortProperties: ['weight'],

  actions: {
    swap: function(line_item_id_1, line_item_id_2) {
      var li1, li1_weight, li2, li2_weight;
      li1 = this.model.get('line_items').findBy('id', line_item_id_1);
      li2 = this.model.get('line_items').findBy('id', line_item_id_2);
      li1_weight = li1.get('weight');
      li2_weight = li2.get('weight');
      li1.set('weight', li2_weight);
      li2.set('weight', li1_weight);
      return Ember.$.ajax({
        url: "/api/v1/ballots/" + (this.model.get('id')) + "/swap/" + (li1.get('id')) + "/" + (li2.get('id')),
        type: 'put'
      }).done(function() {}).fail(function() {
        li1.rollback();
        return li2.rollback();
      });
    }
  }
});

Note the addition of the AJAX call at the end of the swap action in the ballot controller. There is likely a cleaner and more Ember(y) way to do this, and I would love to hear it in the comments below; however, that call got the job done for me and it's good enough to finish out this drag and drop prototype. I opened my console and was pleased to see an AJAX PUT network request after a drop event. Let’s set up our Rails API endpoint.

The Coupling

In my head, I know I want the interaction between my Ember and Rails apps to look like this:

 ----------------                                      -------------------
|                |   PUT: /api/v1/ballots/1/swap/1/2  |                   |
| Ember Frontend |   ==============================>  | Rails API Backend |
|                |                                    |                   |
 ----------------                                      -------------------

That is really all we need. A single endpoint that says "swap the weight of line item 1 and line item 2 on ballot 1." That way, we keep the data on our backend API in sync with that is going on in the Ember frontend.

So, let’s do a little Rails to get this all set up. We are going to generate a ballot controller, then update the routes to access the request to /api/v1/ballots/:id/swap/:li1_id/:li2_id

$ rails g controller Api::V1::Ballots

config/routes.rb

namespace :api do
  namespace :v1 do
    resources :ballots do
      put '/swap/:li1/:li2', to: 'ballots#swap'
    end
  end
end

Then make yourself a controller action for swap.

app/controllers/ballots_controller.rb

class Api::V1::BallotsController < ApplicationController
  respond_to :json

  def swap
    ballot = Ballot.find(params[:ballot_id])
    ballot.swap(LineItem.find(params[:li1]), LineItem.find(params[:li2]))
    if ballot.save
      render json: {}
    else
      render status: 500
    end
  end
end

Lastly, I added this method to my Ballot model to handle swapping line items.

app/models/ballots.rb

def swap(li1, li2)
  li1_weight = li1.weight
  li2_weight = li2.weight
  li1.weight = li2_weight
  li2.weight = li1_weight
  li1.save && li2.save
end

So that should work well. Right?

Dealing with Rails CSRF

That AJAX PUT should have worked but our Rails API is throwing back a crazy error.

ActionController::InvalidAuthenticityToken

What is going on now is that Rails is kicking back our request due to a missing CSRF token. Luckily, there is a CSRF ember npm package we can install that will handle setting the token in all our request headers.

$ npm install --save rails-csrf

Once that is done running, update your app.js to include your new module and your routes/index.js to request the rails CSRF token before page load:

EmberApp/app/app.js

import Ember from 'ember';
import Resolver from 'ember/resolver';
import loadInitializers from 'ember/load-initializers';
import config from './config/environment';

Ember.MODEL_FACTORY_INJECTIONS = true;

var App = Ember.Application.extend({
  modulePrefix: config.modulePrefix,
  podModulePrefix: config.podModulePrefix,
  Resolver: Resolver
});

loadInitializers(App, config.modulePrefix);

//Initialize Rails CSRF
loadInitializers(App, 'rails-csrf');
import { setCsrfUrl } from 'rails-csrf/config';
setCsrfUrl('api/v1/csrf');


export default App;

EmberApp/app/routes/index.js

import Ember from 'ember';

export default Ember.Route.extend({
  controllerName: 'ballot',

  beforeModel: function() {
    return this.csrf.fetchToken();
  },

  model: function() {
    return this.store.find('ballot', 1);
  },
  setupController: function(controller, model){
    controller.set('model', model);
  }
});

Note the addition of "beforeModel." This will request the csrf token from the backend before every page load, but we are not done yet. We need to support this request to /api/v1/csrf in our Rails application.

First, we add this line to our routes.rb file underneath the :api and :v1 namespace declarations.

routes.rb

get :csrf, to: 'csrf#index'

Then we will generate a simple CSRF controller to handle this request.

$ rails g controller Api::V1::Csrf index

csrf_controller.rb

class Api::V1::CsrfController < ApplicationController
  def index
    render json: { request_forgery_protection_token => form_authenticity_token }.to_json
  end
end

Once that is complete. Restart your rails server then reload your Ember app. Now start dragging and dropping to modify your beer rankings. You should see that, on every drop event, an AJAX request is being sent back to the Rails application and updating the line items weights. Now, when you refresh your browser, your updates to beer rankings will be persisted!

Conclusion

While it does take a little work to wire up a Rails/Ember application, they play quite well together! Ember-Data's near perfect compatibility with ActiveModelSerializers makes keeping your models up to date crazy simple. And, with the Rails API becoming a first class citizen with Rails 5, I can see this flow becoming even easier in the coming future. So, if you are not a big fan of integrated frameworks like meteor or volt than using Rails and Ember is a very elegant way to get a lot of work done fast!

Resources

  • Part 1
  • Part 2

Meteor.js is a new framework for real-time web applications. Meteor follows a publish/subscribe pattern effectively recreating a local database with just the subset of data the user is allowed to see. This frees the developer to write database queries both on the client and server.

To bring everyone up to speed on subscriptions before my demo, we watched Matt Debergalis’ video on Meteor.js. The video described how you can subscribe to different channels and make the channels very specific. He also goes into some details about how the security works.

In this video I explain how to structure a Meteor.js application for people familiar with MVC frameworks such as Rails. I use the minimongoid package and coffeescript for powerful models and Iron Router for routing and controllers.

I encourage anyone who is interested in learning more about Meteor.js to watch the demo and feel free to comment on the video if you have any additional questions for Michael. Here is the source code if you would like to try it out yourself:  https://github.com/elfassy/cookbook

It’s no surprise that both Apple and Google want a piece of the $5.1 billion dollar industry that is mobile health. Wearable products like Fitbit have peaked consumer interest in tracking health stats like daily exercise, diet, and sleep patterns. However, with a 50% six month attrition rate, the mHealth community has wondered how to continue to engage people on digital platforms while contemplating the ways the collected data can be used in a meaningful way by health professionals.

An Apple a Day...

Apple announced its new app, Health, on June 2, 2014. The company was smart to partner with Epic Systems and the Mayo Clinic from the start to enhance the credibility of the application. The concept of Health is to aggregate data from different digital sensors such as fitness monitors as well as glucometers. It also adds an emergency medical information card with vital information including the wearer's allergies and current medical conditions.

Google introduced the Fit app as a response to Health on June 25, 2014. Fit is a platform that helps a variety of fitness trackers play nice with Android phones. The basic functionality of both Health and Fit appears similar but what we don’t see from Google is the long-game that Apple is playing by looping in doctors and EMRs (electronic medical records) so the information can be used to better guide patient care.pea

Is there a permanent divide between the two tech giants? Regardless of the current competition, there could be a future merge of Apple with Google via the use of Google Glass. Physicians are increasingly experimenting with Glass in the operating room, to access health records, and to teach medical students and doctors around the world how to perform surgeries. The field of Glass apps is wide open, and as Epic and other EMRs become ubiquitous in hospitals, there is a major opportunity for developers to access APIs for HealthKit and Developer.Fit to try new solutions and bring the most useful parts of each technology together.

The jury is out on whether Apple or Google will dominate personal health data management. Yet there is no doubt that the variety and quality of data collected by sensors like wearables will improve in the near future and shape the ability of physicians to personalize health plans for patients.

Influence in the Triangle Region

Despite the success of these two digital powerhouses, health technology and wearable device research transcends Silicon Valley. So far this year, $2.2 billion in funding has been invested in digital health startups. Several of those startups are located in smaller cities, including an area with a tradition of tech innovation: the Triangle of North Carolina. At Smashing Boxes, we’ve seen interest from non-profits to experiment with Google Glass applications and startups challenging antiquated patient-provider interactions. Moreover, centers like the Duke Institute for Health Innovation are disrupting silos and activating partnerships between doctors and nurses as well as business and software.

To involve health influencers and entrepreneurs in our area, the Triangle Health Startup Weekend is hosted by local organizations annually, with this year’s taking place August 8-10.  We hope to see our neighbors bring forth innovative approaches towards presenting individually monitored health data to physicians in a useful way, as well as considering what could be possible beyond Apple Health and Google Fit. Download our white paper to learn more about empowering patients through mHealth.

Smashing Boxes and the Advanced Self-Powered Systems of Integrated Sensors and Technologies (ASSIST), are proud to announce a partnership to help drive innovation around wearable technology and the Internet of Everything.

Smashing Boxes and ASSIST are both committed to building innovative solutions through creative uses of technology. In line with this commitment, the partnership will further efforts to build the next generation of wearable technology and the software that supports it.

According to Smashing Boxes CEO Nick Jordan, “This partnership will further our commitment to supporting technology innovation in North Carolina. We believe the research and development that ASSIST is producing will help companies build the next generation of wearable technology and make the data they collect more valuable and actionable."

The challenge at present: removing the battery, or the need to charge a battery, from wearable devices. Think nano-enabled energy harvesting, energy storage, nano devices, and sensors to create battery-free, body-powered, and wearable health monitoring systems.

About ASSIST

The NSF Nanosystems Engineering Research Center (NERC) for Advanced Self-Powered Systems of Integrated Sensors and Technologies (ASSIST) develops and employs nano-enabled energy harvesting, energy storage, nanodevices, and sensors to create innovative, battery-free and body-powered wearable health monitoring systems. This center of excellence received funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2012 for five years of research, and this funding will be renewable for another five years in 2017.

Chef is a great tool for automating deployment. But the bootstrap process is hard to get right. Sometimes it can just be easier to start with a system that’s already configured close to your needs.

Setup

  • 64-bit 2011.09 Amazon Linux with EBS boot
  • Nginx latest stable
  • Ruby 1.9.3

First launch an instance from the AWS Management Console. I am using amzn-ami-2011.09.2.x86_64-ebs (ami-1b814f72) as the image.

$ ssh ~/.ec2/yourkey ec2-user@ec2-12-34-56-78.compute-1.amazonaws.com
$ sudo su
$ yum update -y
$ yum install -y openssl-devel zlib-devel gcc gcc-c++ make autoconf readline-devel curl-devel expat-devel gettext-devel pcre-devel
$ wget http://nginx.org/download/nginx-1.0.14.tar.gz</a>"... href="htt...">http://nginx.org/download/nginx-1.0.14.tar.gz">htt...">htt...">http://nginx.org/download/nginx-1.0.14.tar.gz">htt... $ tar xvzf nginx-1.0.14.tar.gz
$ cd nginx-1.0.14
$ ./configure --sbin-path=/usr/local/sbin --with-http_ssl_module
$ make
$ make install

Now you will probably want an init script. This Slicehost article is a bit old but still works beautifully. Start at the “Init Script” section.

Now for ruby, install yaml for psych, and then compile ruby from source:

$ wget http://pyyaml.org/download/libyaml/yaml-0.1.4.tar.... href="http://pyyaml.org/download/libyaml/yaml-0.1.4.tar....">http://pyyaml.org/download/libyaml/yaml-0.1.4.tar.... $ tar xzvf yaml-0.1.4.tar.gz
$ cd yaml-0.1.4
$ ./configure --prefix=/usr/local
$ make && make install
$ wget http://pyyaml.org/download/libyaml/yaml-0.1.4.tar.... href="http://ftp.ruby-lang.org/pub/ruby/1.9/ruby-1.9.3-p...">http://ftp.ruby-lang.org/pub/ruby/1.9/ruby-1.9.3-p... $ tar xvzf ruby-1.9.3-p125.tar.gz
$ cd ruby-1.9.3-p125
$ ./configure --prefix=/usr/local --disable-install-doc --with-opt-dir=/usr/local/lib
$ make && make install
$ /usr/local/bin/gem install bundler

Now clean up:

$ rm -rf ruby* nginx* yaml*
$ cd /var/log
$ > cron
$ > maillog 
$ > secure
$ > spooler 
$ > yum.log 
$ rm ~/.bash_history
$ exit

Now we’re ready to create the image. Right click on the EC2 instance in the AWS control panel and choose “Create Image (EBS AMI)”. Give it a name and description and then click “create”. Now choose the AMIs tab on the left. You should see the new AMI in the “pending” status.

body:
or You Know, Just Web Design

“The web is responsive on its own—by default. It's us that's been breaking it all these years by placing content in fixed-width containers.”

— Viljami S. (@viljamis) December 1, 2012

Welcoming  a new  year is as good a time as any for reflection, and there are few things on the Web more deserving of thoughtful contemplation than Responsive Web Design (RWD). Rivaled only by HTML5 in terms of buzzword status and pedestal placement, our mysterious stranger tore down most of the walls that width: 960px; built.

In the resulting excitement, some developers hailed RWD as the saviour of us all, while others tried it and swore it off as a time-sink. Still others are waiting for RWD to blow over so we can get back to making websites. Additionally, device makers are coming to the same realization as everyone else — we are no longer constrained to an area the size of a sheet of paper. Amidst all the fuss, I noticed plenty of confusion about it at all levels.

What Responsive Is.

RWD is the idea and methodology behind creating websites that respond to the user’s environment and behaviors. Screen size, device orientation, and resolution all factor into how the content is displayed to the user. The use of media queries, fluid grids, and flexible media all work together to provide an optimal viewing experience. Rather than multiple codebases for each target screen size, a single codebase serves all users.

Many have defined, refined and enhanced responsive’s basic definition, but the following is all we really need to understand the approach. Media queries, fluid grids, and flexible media aren’t just the trappings of a responsive website, they are the core techniques of the practice. Media queries allow the application of different CSS depending on screen dimensions and orientation. Fluid grids structure the site design around ratios rather than fixed values (i.e. 960px) and allow sites to conform to different screen sizes. Media assets adapt to device sizes allowing users a more complete experience regardless of how they access the site.

Anyone who built websites over the past year likely heard the above terms on a daily basis. However, responsive web design hasn’t been the topic  du jour for all that long. To help illustrate the recency of the responsive web conversation, I’ve included Google Trends data on related terms below (embedded):

The data doesn’t exactly represent any peer-reviewed research, but you can get a feel for how long the terms have been relevant. Around May 2010 queries for RWD and its constituent terms really start to lift. Ethan Marcotte published “ Responsive Web Design” on A List Apart around the same time, drawing parallels to the architectural concept of the same name.

What’s the point here? I can’t think of the last project I worked on where a responsive website wasn’t at least considered, if not actually included and launched. As a developer, responsive design is part of my day-to-day considerations, but the concept has only met wide discussion in the last few years and applied on a large scale for even less time. Yes, the Web moves fast but this isn’t just a new coding technique or browser feature — what we’re looking at is a fundamental shift in paradigms. An object’s width is one of its most basic properties, and the width of the Web is changing.

What Responsive Isn’t.

With so many benefits to having a site that can dress for any occasion, why not just make that the norm and usher in a new, device-agnostic era on the Web? As an overly excited web developer, that was certainly my first impulse. However, responsive design isn’t “the solution” and depending on your situation it may not address any of your major problems.

It really doesn’t matter what numbers you look at, mobile web use is up. Way up. All the way up. And traffic is only slated to increase. When the majority of users were on desktop browsers we could set a page’s width to the narrowest of the target screen resolutions and be pretty safe. Now, a user might access your site not only on a smartphone, but from several different non-desktop devices in the course of completing a single task.

Users’ changing usage patterns will impact any Web-bound project you start, therefore it’s increasingly important to analyze your target audience before deciding on what approach to take. If your site analytics show that most visits come from IE8 workstations, no level of responsiveness will improve those users’ experience. By the same token, if your primary demographic turns out to be tablet and mobile users, just adding a few media queries can vastly improve how your site renders on those devices.

The key takeaway is that responsive design is a technique. It’s not a framework, or a toolkit, or a plugin or anything else but a method of problem solving. Similar to all problem-solving techniques, responsive isn’t suited for every problem. There are cases where having a separate mobile and desktop site is quicker, cheaper, or more effective than a responsive site that caters to every device. Smashing Magazine published an in-depth comparison of 2012′s presidential candidates’ mobile approaches (one responsive, one with a separate mobile site) to solving the same problem, that helps to underline the challenges inherent in both techniques.

Where to now?

RWD is arguably the most popular of several attempts to cope with and adapt to a changing problem space. Just think, if painters were only ever shown an 8.5×11-inch canvas, then suddenly given a nearly infinite number of width and height combinations to work with, they too would need to take stock. They would likely need to reexamine everything they thought they knew about composition. Perhaps they would develop techniques for dealing with especially large or small canvases. Whatever the outcome, once the painters learned to deal with the new variable in their workflow, they would return to task: painting.

The metaphor may be a little shaky since paintings usually don’t have to “respond” to different canvas sizes, but I think the point stands. Every time the problem space changes, those who work within that space adapt their methods and continue producing. The need for responsive websites will not go away, but building a “responsive website” instead of just a website is the same as building an “good SEO website” or an “HTML5 website”. All these things are merely attributes, they are not the site itself.

If web design is problem solving, every website is a solution to a specific problem. How effectively a particular site solves the problem has nothing to do with which framework or how many media queries it uses. Instead, a site’s effectiveness relies on how carefully its developer chooses its constituent components and how well those components work together to address the original problem.

Earlier this month, our Experience Design department took a field trip to the Porsche by Design exhibit at the North Carolina Museum of Art. Exploring the history and development of the Porsche lineage from the 1930s to today, the exhibit featured dozens of cars, accompanied by videos and photographs, that helped the team to reflect on the experience engendered by their singular design and engineering. The following are our design team’s thoughts and reactions upon visiting the exhibit

Dante (Director of User Experience)

On the surface, there are two obvious themes running through the Porsche by Design exhibit: 1) precision design and engineering and 2) the emotional connection between machine and operator. The vehicles were, of course, striking, but the part of the exhibit that most resonated with me were the accompanying photographs of engineers, factory workers, and the Porsche family, themselves. It’s interesting how we glorify beautiful objects, while somehow forgetting that flesh and blood human beings actually conceived of, designed, and built the objects. Their humanity and vision drove their craft and set their creations apart. Just as important to me were the people to whom these cars belonged. Again, these were real, live people with a passion (sometimes an obsession) for a particular feeling that only a Porsche could give them. I, personally, am a Mopar man, but those cars weren’t built for me. They weren’t built for my grandma and they weren’t built based on a persona created by a research department. They were built for Porsche drivers, a market that didn’t exist until the first Porsches started rolling out of the workshop.

So why did that move me? Why is it important at all? It’s simple – if a group of men created enduring beauty that speaks to something in the hearts of other men, then so could I. That’s maybe the most trite, cliche thing I’ve ever written, but it’s a desire that I’ve felt is sometimes lacking in the user experience field. There’s a tendency to design based solely on convention, frameworks, and the insights of a select few “thought leaders”. That’s a great way to deliver something that won’t fail, but should avoiding failure be your goal as a UX professional? Or should it be to innovate and inspire wherever possible? Should you make important decisions based on research that’s been abstracted and extrapolated to the point of losing all basis in reality, or should you rely on your instinct, your gut? I know that there’s a place for plug-n-chug, and I’m not one to reinvent the wheel, but it’s incumbent on us to take every opportunity to inject our humanity into the products that we build. If your average UX team is comfortable building Honda Civics for a wide swath of people to be completely stupefied by, that’s great. There’s a place for that. Me, I want to build Porsches.

Lucas (User Experience)

Each model, from the 356 (first produced in 1948) all the way up to more recent 911 models, was both unique and also connected to the overall evolution of Porsche design. Frame and body design, headlight housing, interior cabins, exhaust systems, paint jobs, etc., varied greatly between models, but you always knew you were looking at a Porsche. It seemed each design achieved a high level of style and character primarily through the exceptional care taken to exceed functional requirements. By artfully meeting functional needs and working with strong overall design foundations of the Porsche brand, designers were able to go in bold new directions. The evolution of design within the Porsche line seemed to serve as a foundation for the transition to new and innovative designs. In the following video, Daniel Weil does a great job of articulating the thought process that designers go through as a product design is developed and refined over time. Although the product is extremely different (in Weil’s case it is a baby bottle), the overall care taken to address functional requirements is not unlike Porsche design.

Doug (Design)

The thing that stuck out to me the most when our team visited the NC Art Museum’s Porsche By Design exhibit was the elegant simplicity of some of the earlier models of Porsches. The colors were classic, the curves were refined, the details were subtle, and the racing liveries were bold. In my opinion, the older models felt like they were a lot more in line with the designers’ initial visions even keeping in mind the fact that times have changed, technology has changed, and that design trends have come and gone.

I think it was Da Vinci who said, “Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.” Porsche has always created amazing cars, but those earlier models were really amazing. Stripped of, or altogether void of, the amenities and nice-to-haves that are commonplace on today’s cars (I don’t think I saw a single cup holder in the exhibit). They had a unified and balanced feel to them. Getting to see all of these cars was really inspirational and it got me thinking about the work that I do. It seems all too common today to jam-pack cars, web pages, logos, songs, you name it, with far too much unnecessary…stuff. So whether we’re talking about features, content, colors, elements, or shiny distractions, the most memorable solutions are often the most simple. /rant

All in all though, this exhibit was awesome. It was really cool to see all of these cars and some of the concept cars that never made it to production.

Raleigh (Director of Design)

When thinking about “design” at Smashing Boxes we do not just think about how something looks. We approach design as the overall experience of the users exploring our sites or applications we have built.

The design department loves and lives by this R. Buckminster Fuller quote: “When I am working on a problem, I never think about beauty but when I have finished, if the solution is not beautiful, I know it is wrong.”

The Porsche exhibit was a great display of beautifully designed machinery. When I say “designed,” I am not referencing just the outer body of the car, which is by the way, very pleasing to the eye. I am talking about the overall car itself. Everything on a Porsche is designed intentionally, there is little to no fluff. For everything that makes up the vehicle, there is a reason. Porsche cars perform at the highest level all the while looking beautiful.

At Smashing Boxes, we approach every project by asking the question, “How can we build something that performs well and looks great?” We try and look at design the same way Porsche does — if an application looks nice, but doesn’t perform well, then it is not designed. Similarly, the app is not well designed if it has optimal performance, but is not appealing to the eye. We care about how it functions, how it performs, and how it looks.

A quote beside the Porsche 356 that said, “People who own Porsche’s may be anything from industrial tycoon to freelance artist, but they all have two things in common: 1) When they want to go, they want to go; they don’t want temperament, delay, or fussiness in their automobiles; 2) They don’t live in ugly houses, they don’t wear ugly clothes, and they don’t drive ugly automobiles.” “You almost never see a Porsche driver who looks bored.

We want the same thing to be said about the products we build. We make sure users are not temperamental, delayed, or frustrated in the experiences we “design.” We also want people to look at our visual design and understand the confidence it brings to the user. In the end we want every user to have nice, well-crafted experiences with everything we build.

We’d love to hear your thoughts about the Porsche by Design exhibit, Porsche, or design. Let us know if you visited the exhibit and have any design-related thoughts to share by commenting below.

Check out our latest design work and experimentation on Dribbble.
summary: Earlier this month, our Experience Design department took a field trip to the Porsche by Design exhibit at the North Carolina Museum of Art. Exploring the history and development of the Porsche lineage from the 1930s to today, the exhibit featured dozens of cars, accompanied by videos and photographs, that helped the team to reflect…
title: Porsche By Design

body:
Why?

To say that Ember has grown over the past year would be an understatement. The Ember community has been exploding with awesome new tools to make developing and testing your Ember applications easier than ever. I am a Rails developer and when I first started working with Ember, the fastest way for me to get up and running was to use ember-rails and seriously tweak my the asset pipeline. It wasn't all bad at first but as ember-cli started to become the de-facto standard for new Ember apps I felt myself getting left in the dust. Once I heard that ember-cli was going to become a first class citizen in Ember v2 I decided to quit dragging my feet and get on board with the new way to build Ember apps

The App

What I needed to build was an application where users could rank their favorite beers via a drag-and-drop ordering UI. Here is what I came up with:

While not 100% fleshed out from a UX point of view this interface was surprisingly simple to implement. In the past I would of had to write a mountain of javascript just to get all the AJAX calls right. THEN I would go out and find some JQuery plugin, become an expert in it and click around in my element inspector for hours until everything was just right.

Not anymore, I only used the following combination of tools

  • Rails
  • ember-cli
  • HTML5 drag-and-drop

Rails API

The Rails API was crazy simple. I used active_model_serializers and just a handfull of rails-generated models.

Generate a new rails app w/o sprockets
sh $ rails new App --skip-sprockets $ cd App

Update Gemfile

source 'https://rubygems.org'

gem 'rails', '4.1.6'
gem 'sqlite3'
gem 'active_model_serializers'

Bundle Install

$ bundle install

I'm not going to dive into the details of the API. If you want to see the models, routes, serializers, and controllers then you can look at the codebase here. If you have any questions then please feel free to post them in the comments bellow. :)

Once you have your API built out, you should have the following 2 endpoints ready that your Ember app can talk to. PUT /api/v1/ballots/:ballot_id/swap/:li1/:li2(.:format) GET /api/v1/ballots/:id(.:format) All we will be doing is getting a ballot and swapping the line_items on that ballot when we drag a beer over another beet. Super simple!

Ember

Now the good stuff. Assuming you want to follow along, install node/npm and ember-cli on your machine sh $ brew install node $ npm install -g ember-cli

Next we will generate our ember app. sh $ ember new EmberApp

ember-cli is going to go to work standing up the structure of a very basic ember app. It will also setup package managment with bower and asset complication with broccoli. This will allow you to use ES6 module syntax, sass, handlebars, coffeescript, and other transpiles languages that you like.

Now, startup your Ember app. sh $ cd EmberApp $ ember server

You should see this output

And you will see the following @ localhost:4200

Now, we will start writing Ember. I like to setup my adapter and generate my models first. For this blog post we will be using ember-data.

$ ember generate adapter application
$ ember generate model Ballot
$ ember generate model LineItem

Update your generated EmberApp/app/adapters/application.js. We will need to update our adaptor namespace to /api/v1. Then we need to tell Ember to use the ActiveModelAdapter. Ember, out of the box, knows how to communicate with a Rails app using ActiveRecordSerializers. We will also tell it the namespace of our api.

import DS from 'ember-data';

export default DS.ActiveModelAdapter.extend({
  namespace: 'api/v1',
});

Now open the generated EmberApp/app/models/line-item.js model to find a lot of ember-cli generated javascript! We used to have to do all this tedious work to wire up our models by hand, but now ember-cli handles all this for us. All we need to do is define the attributes for a line item.

import DS from 'ember-data';

export default DS.Model.extend({
  beer_name: DS.attr('string'),
  weight: DS.attr('number'),
  ballot: DS.belongsTo('ballot'),
});

Ballot will be a little bit different. We are going to use a computed property called sorted_line_items to sort the ballot's line-items by weight. This will be important since we want to be able to re-arrange the sorted list of beers. Open EmberApp/app/models/ballot.js and update the js with the following.

import DS from 'ember-data';

export default DS.Model.extend({
  line_items: DS.hasMany('line_items'),

  sorted_line_items: (function(){
    return this.get('line_items').sortBy('weight');
  }).property('line_items.@each.weight'),
});

Next, generate a ballot controller and a line-item view. These don't need to be modified yet. sh $ ember generate controller Ballot $ ember generate view LineItem

Finally, we will create an index route. sh $ ember generate route index

This will generate an EmberApp/app/routes/index.js route file and index.hbs handlebars template. We'll now go into these files and define what controller and model we will want to use.

import Ember from 'ember';

export default Ember.Route.extend({
  controllerName: 'ballot',

  model: function() {
    return this.store.find('ballot', 1);
  },

  setupController: function(controller, model){
    controller.set('model', model);
  }
});

Then we will define a simple view at EmberApp/app/templates/index.hbs.

<div class='container'>
  <div class='container'>
    <ol>
      {{#each controller.model.sorted_line_items}}
        <li>
          {{beer_name}}
        </li>
      {{/each}}
    </ul>
  </div>
</div>

Rails

The Rails side of this application is pretty simple. A single controller, for getting ballots and a basic model structure that looks like this.

 --------            ----------           ------
|        |  1  0..* |          |  1    1 |      |
| Ballot | <======= | LineItem | ======> | Beer |
|        |          |  weight  |         | name |
 --------            ----------           ------

A little rails generate magic should get us pretty far.

$ rails g model Ballot
$ rails g model Beer name:string
$ rails g model LineItem ballot:references beer:references weight:integer

Then I just made a tiny ballot in my seeds that we can use to play with for this app

db/seeds.rb

Beer.delete_all
Ballot.delete_all

b1 = Beer.create!(name: 'Goose Island IPA')
b2 = Beer.create!(name: 'Dogfish Head 90 Min IPA')
b3 = Beer.create!(name: 'Mother Earth Oatmeal Stout')
b4 = Beer.create!(name: 'Raleigh Brewing Mocha Stout')

Ballot.create!(beers: [b1, b2, b3, b4], user_id: 1)

Lastly, I created a BallotsController and route so that my Ember app has a ballot that it can grab from the Rails app.

app/controllers/api/v1/ballots_controller.rb

class Api::V1::BallotsController < ApplicationController
  respond_to :json

  def show
    render json: Ballot.first
  end
end

app/serializers/ballot_serializer.rb

class BallotSerializer < ActiveModel::Serializer
  embed :ids, include: true
  attributes :id
  has_many :line_items, serializer: LineItemSerializer
end

config/routes.rb

Rails.application.routes.draw do
  namespace :api do
    namespace :v1 do
      resources :ballots
    end
  end
end

Once that is done, initialize a Rails server...

$ rails s

...and then initialize your Ember app via ember-cli but you will need to tell ember to talk to localhost:3000 which should be where your rails app is hosted at.

$ ember server --proxy http://localhost:3000

Once your ember server is up and running, point your browser to localhost:4200 and you will see this. Dont forget to seed your database!

Resources

  • App Repo
  • ember-cli

In part two, I'll go into detail about how I implemented HTML5 drag-n-drop functionality for updating beer rankings. I will demonstrate how simple it was to build this functionality into my existing, non-dynamic list of beers.

body:
In a profession that is largely subjective and inspired, such as design, adopting a process can provide a framework for creation that elevates the quality of your work. Though a process leads us through similar steps for each project, it keeps our work fresh and exciting as we never know what we will uncover and the result is different each time.

Even after 15 years as a designer, my team and I begin each project wondering 'how in the world are we going to solve this client’s problem?’ That’s because starting can be the greatest challenge in the creative process. Having a defined and flexible process provides a clear beginning, and a framework for each step after. Though our clients and the problems they have may be wildly different from project to project, our flexible process keeps us focused and helps us to be more objective about our work.

In this video series capturing my talk at AIGA Raleigh I go into detail about our design process. This is part one in a four part video series. I hope you enjoy it and are able to take away some knowledge that you can apply to your own work.

body:
Like the majority of college graduates, Alison Miller and Lindsay Nauman didn’t major in computer science. In 2009, graduates of their major, communications and journalism, outnumbered computer science majors two to one. As technology continues to grow exponentially worldwide, and demand for developers and engineers hastens, employers are finding themselves in a bind. Computer and mathematical occupations in the U.S. are expected to grow by almost 800,000 jobs by 2018, and it doesn’t take an engineer to tell you that universities are not keeping up with demand.

Alison Miller, a graduate of The Iron Yard Academy in Greenville, SC

Miller, a 2009 graduate of Arizona State University, had only dabbled with HTML and CSS in her job as a digital content editor. “I’d have to say my coding skills were pretty limited,” she recalls.

Nauman also had limited coding experience. After graduating from Temple University in 2009, she sent out demo reels to news stations across the country with no luck. While continuing to look for jobs in her field, she made money by bartending and taking on side jobs such as selling real estate, none of which made use of her degree. “A lot of the jobs I was applying for required skills I didn’t have so I took a web design certification program to acquire them. I fell head over heels in love with technology,” says Nauman. She thought she might be able to teach herself to code, but knew it would take considerable time and would be hard to learn that way. “I wanted to be immersed.”

Lindsay Nauman, a graduate of Launch Academy in Boston

Enter code school; one solution to help close the employment gap and bring motivated individuals an opportunity for career growth. Offering crash courses in high-demand software languages, code schools give non-developers an opportunity to secure a better job with their new programming skills. Typically three months in length, they combine teaching and mentorship with real world development work. “Successful schools center their curriculum around practical application” says Eric Dodds of The Iron Yard Academy , a nationally respected code academy based out of Greenville, S.C. “By the end, students emerge as professional, junior-level programmers.” Nauman and Miller are both graduates of a code school, and they’ve found their lives transformed by it.

Code academies, when done right, are profoundly challenging. “The information I read about the code school described the academy as boot camp style and super intense,” recalls Nauman who attended Launch Academy in Boston. “I completely underestimated what that meant. I have always been able to pick things up quickly so I was like, I’ve got this! It was the hardest, but most rewarding thing I’ve ever done. I spent easily 10-14 hours a day, 7 days a week in school or studying; basically eating, sleeping, and breathing code. It was much harder than I expected.”

Miller, who attended The Iron Yard Academy, agrees, “It was overwhelming at first. There were lots of long and stressful nights of coding, and I definitely questioned my ability at times. But, as the program progressed, all of the pieces started falling together.”

After completing intensive three month courses, neither graduate had trouble finding a programming job. “There were a lot of opportunities for junior software developers,” says Nauman. “I had a ton of interviews, and second interviews. Once you have the skills, the hard part isn’t getting the interviews, it’s making sure you find a company that is a good cultural fit for you. One that encourages continual learning.” She now works as a back-end developer for Smashing Boxes.

Miller was able to secure a job as an Interaction Engineer at Benefitfocus by showcasing her portfolio on GitHub. “I landed about ten interviews and received three job offers within the first month after completing the program,” says Miller.

Both Miller and Nauman have seen their salaries double since graduating from the program and accredit their success to code school. “I really didn’t know what to expect when I decided to enroll in The Iron Yard Academy,” says Miller, “I was taking a leap, both personally and financially. It definitely paid off. I feel like I have a great career path ahead of me.”

Nauman couldn’t agree more, “I sometimes stand back and can’t believe this is my life right now. I was bartending and now I’m a software developer at one of the coolest companies ever, working with and learning from such smart people, doing something that excites and challenges me on a daily, no, an hourly basis. I’m literally living my dream.”

Learn more about Durham’s first code school, The Iron Yard Academy powered by Smashing Boxes, at the American Underground.

When I wrote about Heroku and Amazon Web Services a few months ago it seemed both services were equally worthwhile in many respects. My rule of thumb was: small app–Heroku; large app–Amazon. Since then a few events have caused me to reevaluate my position.

Heroku’s customer non-service

Recently, Heroku revealed a new site interface. In the past if you needed something you could open up a free support ticket. Now the only options for free support are the docs or Stack Overflow. Yes, they actually link to Stack Overflow on their new help page. Ticket History is still visible, but there is no way to open up a new ticket.

Granted, AWS doesn’t provide much more than Heroku. But AWS does have a free forum where Amazon employees reply to users’ support questions.

I recently had an issue related to billing with Heroku. Heroku offered a beta period for their new database stack allowing developers to try out their new databases free of charge. I added a couple for testing believing they would remain free until their general release in August. Heroku’s blog post indicated they would notify users prior to billing them.

I assumed there would be an additional step needed to opt-in before being billed, but this was not the case. The only notice I found was a note in one of their email newsletters (which I never read). The notice was one sentence in the middle of the email (underlined in red).

Nearly two months later, I discovered we had accumulated several hundred dollars in charges for databases that we weren’t even using. I tried writing them back at their billing@heroku.com account, but it’s been three weeks and I have not received a response.

How AWS would have prevented this

Around the same time that I noticed the excessive Heroku charges, I logged into our AWS account. What a pleasant surprise to be greeted with a message telling me how to set up notifications for estimated cost triggers. (I already use Amazon’s Simple Notification Service for CPU usage alerts on our EC2 instances.) The alerts are easy to configure due to an intuitive web interface. After establishing a preferred trigger, you can review the past few days’ activity which shows when the trigger would have activated. I immediately set up cost alerts for my AWS account. AWS was nice enough to place the cost alert feature in a prominent place where everyone should see it. Heroku may have a similar feature, but I have not found it.

The billing issue is a small concern, but it illustrates how mature AWS has become while Heroku’s new interface is somewhat of a regression. In the future I will explore how to get up and running on AWS, and how to leverage Ruby gems to achieve similar functionality to that offered by Heroku.

body:
People have long been fascinated with a future where humans and machines become one. Science fiction author Philip K. Dick (adapted films include Blade Runner and Minority Report to name a few) describes a world where high-tech enhancements increase our ability to process information. This allows us to become superhuman. This co-evolution of technology and physiology is no longer the stuff of science fiction. It will shape the story of the 21st Century.

With that said, we are still in the toddler phase of the “wearable” generation. Much of what we “touch” currently is just noise in the form of data. There are hundreds of devices that monitor everything from sleep to blood glucose. To make this data relevant, these devices must communicate with each other and provide a smarter interpretation of the data. And there is still much to be desired where battery life and wearable interfaces are concerned. We can dig into what’s being done to break down these barriers in a bit, but first we should probably answer the big question: Why does this matter?

Let’s begin with some predictions.

Where I think wearables will make the most impact in the next five years:

Data Facilitated Care

What is it: Embedded biometric sensors and software that provide continuous capture, delivery and interpretation of health and performance. This allows physicians, care teams and coaches to make prescriptive decisions quickly and from anywhere.

Biometric sensors embedded in clothing. Photo Credit: Keoni Cabral


Dr. David Berkoff, Sports Medicine Physician at UNC Department of Orthopaedics explains. “One of the main objectives right now is to improve continuity of care,” he said. “Currently we get a very inconsistent snapshot of a patients health. They come in for a visit, we review the data presented that day and make decisions.” According to Dr. Berkoff, “with ‘wearables’ we are close to having continuous, accurate data about an individual's physiology and daily behaviors. This is key to empowering healthcare professionals to make better decisions and help drive behavior change and outcomes.”

Personalized Wearables

What is it: ‘Made to fit’ sensor-enabled apparel and medical devices that use advances in 3D printing technology to personalize the experience for an individual.

According to a recent article in Quartz, Nike is using advances in nano-technology to embed sensors in their apparel. This combined with the ability to print an individual t-shirt with a 3D enabled printer will allow people to customize their apparel. Athletes and coaches will better understand when they are overtraining or under-training, and when they are under hydrated and overstressed. It will also reduce the cost of production and management of the supply chain for companies like Nike.

Photo Credit: Atos

Sensor-embedded 3D printing will also impact the medical device industry. Mayo Clinic has already produced its first custom hip. They are looking for ways to embed sensors in the devices to improve monitoring of a patient's function and wear and tear on the joint.

Active Coaching

What is it: Sensor-embedded hardware and apparel that monitor performance, provide interpretation and make suggestions on how to progress. This next step in wearable technology will help individuals improve everything from their fitness to their biomechanics (posture and gait for example).

One of the keys for active coaching to be successful is to improve the validity of the data and interpretation. Dr. Steven LeBoeuf, Founder and President of Valencell says, “one reason we started with optical signal sensor based technology in the ear was the validity of the data.”

The next step, according to LeBoeuf is to make the data relevant to improve engagement. “We need good data and then software that accurately interprets the data and provides useful advice on how to progress to make a dent in improving health and fitness outcomes.”

Gesture Based Interfacing

What is it: Empowers individuals to use gestures and other natural movements to interplay with devices. By adopting everyday movements and gestures in lieu of complex machine based tasks, we can improve the user experience and make it easier for people to onboard to new devices and software.

We’ve already seen the beginning of gesture-based interfacing with Google Glass which lets users take a picture by blinking. Photo Credit: CyberHades


According to recent patents from Apple, their new Watch may allow for gesture-based adaptive learning. This may communicate actions like navigating through Apple TV, flipping pages on your iPad while running on a treadmill, shutting off the lights, and more.

Authenticated You

What is it: Wearables have the ability to provide a unique signature to the individual. Using unique characteristics such as heart rhythm could take the place of outdated credentialing methods like a written password.

How many times have you forgotten your password or had your email hacked? This could soon be a problem of the past. New technologies like watch-enabled heart rate monitors can measure one’s unique rhythm and convert it to a password. Other companies are creating ingestibile technology that allows external devices to log in when the individual is near. Acid in the stomach powers the battery.

Barriers To Success

According to a report from Juniper Research, the wearable tech market is expected to expand rapidly within the next few years. The firm projects that the wearable tech market will hit $4.5 billion by the end of 2014, and reach $53.2 billion by 2019. This is great news for OEMs who are investing heavily in wearable tech initiatives. However, several things need to fall into place in order for this market opportunity to achieve its full potential.

  • Increased Battery Life
  • Improved User Experience
  • Making Data Useful

Death By Discharge

One of the key issues challenging wearable device engagement at the six month mark is the inconvenience of having to charge it. According to LeBoeuf, industry statistics show that as soon as someone takes off the device there is a more than one third chance they won’t put it back on.

“When you have to take your device off to charge it, you immediately disengage the user and they begin to wonder how much value they are getting by counting steps.” This is what LeBoeuf calls “death by discharge.” “If their experience with the device is a good one, then they will likely put it back on but if not it may become best friends with the underwear drawer,” he said.

Dr. Berkoff agrees. “As an athlete, it’s one of my biggest frustrations...I’m ready to go on a long ride and I forgot to charge my device,” he said. He also sees battery life as a big barrier to getting regular joes to purchase the devices, “If it’s a problem for early adopters, then you know it’s going to be an issue for everyone else.”

Organizations like Advanced Self-Powered Systems of Integrated Sensors and Technologies(ASSIST) at North Carolina State University are working on solving the battery life issue. They are developing technologies to enable battery free and body powered devices. Tom Snyder, Industry Liaison for ASSIST explains, “we are utilizing nanotechnology to bring the energy requirement for sensors and wireless data transmission down to a level that your body can be utilized as a power supply.” As an example, ASSIST materials, embedded in a textile can harvest energy from the temperature difference between the skin and air, and use this to power the sensors. This not only has an impact on clothing but also on medical devices. They’re currently working on a battery free pacemaker.

Human-Centered Design Will Be Key

Marrying a relevant user experience with the appropriate interface will be key. Sensors embedded in a shirt to free up space coupled with a watch interface that delivers the information from clothing is one example. Another example of providing a good user experience is embedding technology in devices that are familiar, like headphones.

“We started with headphones because our audience were athletes and weekend warriors,” said LeBoeuf. “They already wore headphones when they worked out so it made sense. Why make them work harder and purchase another device?”

According to an industry report by Rock Health, a health incubator and fund based in San Francisco, California, one of the biggest barriers to engagement is at the onset of using the device. Meaning, quite literally, the pain of getting it out of the box and setting it up. Reports indicate that close to 10 percent of technology products are returned before they are even used.

Fashion is also an important element in adoption; it’s about both form and function. Technology software and hardware designers are not accustomed to the nuances of fashion design. Consider the success of the smartphone, given it is typically stuffed in our pockets. If wearables are to succeed, brands must immerse themselves in fashion trends and psychology to inspire design.

Getting Personal

In 2013, over 70 million wearable devices were sold and by 2016 that number will reach over 90 million. With that said, the adoption rate will slow or decline if these devices don’t provide more meaning and context about how to improve our health, fitness, and life based upon our goals and needs.

To truly connect the data, simplifying the communication between devices through a universal API will become critically important. It will start when devices talk to each other. Thanks to your phone’s G.P.S., RFID, or Bluetooth, you’ll get a personalized workout plan the second you arrive at the gym and adjust the intensity based upon your previous workout, cortisol levels and hydration. The device will know that it took longer for you to fall into REM sleep because home sensors indicate that you kept the lights on.

A number of companies including Nike are already moving towards coach-enhanced apps that learn from your performance outputs and adjusts your next workout accordingly. Apple’s new health and fitness app will tell you when you need to stand or move more (two keys to cardiovascular health) based upon real time information from their Watch. In addition to Apple and Nike, a number of other companies are hiring teams of exercise physiologists, data scientists, and physicians to help move data from descriptive to prescriptive.

Dr. Berkoff agrees that for devices to be adopted by the mainstream they have to provide more than just entertaining data to the user. “Physicians and their patients need to understand how they are progressing and if there is the need for an intervention,” he said. “Data is just data without proper interpretation and there may be times where the physicians don’t have time during a clinic visit to interpret the data. We just need to know when to connect with the patient.”

Dr. Berkoff says that sports medicine physicians, physical therapists and other healthcare professionals can benefit from the continuous monitoring and interpretation of movement. “I can only get so much information in a 10-15 minute office visit,” he explained. “I may watch someone walk or run during that visit, but they may be on their best behavior giving me less than perfect data. To really understand how they move and to make the best prescription we would benefit from continuous monitoring and feedback which we could then use to provide the patient with a better plan on how to progress and improve.”

The Future Is Already Here...Sort Of

Companies and startups are already creating new ways to measure health and performance and help people be more productive. Parents and their children are finding significant value in products like Sqord - the first wearable for kids that helps curb childhood obesity and improve children’s health. It uses sensors to track activity and provides feedback and motivation to help kids move more.

Companies like Fitlinxx are also changing the game with their new product, AmpStrip. The heart rate and activity tracking monitor is designed to stick to the wearer’s torso and be left for a week or more at a time. Once they’re done with it, they can remove it like a bandaid and recharge, add adhesive and put it back on.

While wearable technology is still in its infancy, the growth and excitement around them will ensure the technology matures rapidly over the next few years.

summary: While wearable technology is still in its infancy, the growth and excitement around them will ensure the technology matures rapidly over the next few years.
title: Five Predictions For The Future of Wearables
