I’m not a programmer...more of a product developer who understands just enough code to be dangerous. About a month ago I graduated from code school and after twelve weeks of intense training, my two teammates and I put ourselves through the challenge of designing a health app in under two and half weeks. What we learned is something that all developers and UX designers know - to create a successful product, the discovery phase has to be thought out, well-planned and well implemented. Here I’ll talk about leveraging lean startup methodology to build software and show exactly how we delivered it in the form of a mobile health app.

Phase One: Discovery (3 days)

Step One: Defining the Problem

The discovery phase of the product development process is critical for uncovering the “real” problems that need to be solved. It’s also important in helping define the initial target audience or user base. The initial product, or minimum viable product (MVP), will need to be tested with that audience or user base to learn as much as possible about them with as little effort as possible. More on this in a minute. Failing to select the correct audience and “jobs” they need to accomplish can kill the product's success.

The first step is to identify the problem. In our case Josh, our lead backend developer, explained that he was having trouble staying motivated and accountable to a health plan called the Primal Blueprint. It was a plan focused more on improving health than bench pressing 300 lbs. or running a three-hour marathon. It focused on improving sleep quality, eating well and moving enough.

After a couple months, he would get bored with his meal plan and return to eating poorly. Josh also lacked awareness in regards to how he was performing on the plan...he was losing weight and feeling better...but was he sleeping enough? Was he moving enough during the day? There was no definition of success. So we concluded that the best product to test (the MVP) was a health app.

As an exercise physiologist I try to keep up with the most recent research. Based upon some recent studies, the current thinking is that maintaining and improving one’s health is not defined only by working out intensely for 30-60 minutes per day (although that is important) it’s also defined by not being sedentary (i.e. resting your backside eight hours per day). It’s also key, especially when designing a health application, that you have someone on your team that understands the domain. The more familiar you are with the subject matter the more depth and value you can typically add to a product. With this in mind we decided to test our assumption that other people had these problems as well. MVP hypothesizing at work.

Step Two: Understand Your Audience

Ideation can take on many forms, but when testing a minimum viable product, assumptions have to be made quickly and with a gut feeling. When Zappos founder Nick Swinmurn wanted to test the hypothesis that customers were willing to buy shoes online, he got right down to it. He didn’t build a brand new website or ship in an entire stockroom of shoes, but instead took pictures of a local shoe store’s inventory, posted the pictures online, bought the shoes from the store at full price, and sold them directly to customers. Like Swinburn, we assumed customer demand was present, and in this case it was the demand for a more involved health app they could use.

We had limited time (literally a day) to complete the hypothesis testing process. I did some basic research on Primal Blueprint, performed some basic audience research by viewing their forums and Facebook page, and had a short storyboarding session with the team.

Following the lean methodology process, we made a number of assumptions:

  • There were enough people on the Primal Blueprint plan that had problems similar to those Josh was experiencing
  • The initial audience that had the most pain and was most likely to adopt the product early were age 22-30, male leaning, recent college graduates living in metropolitan areas and were Achiever Intellectual archetype (send me a message if you want to know more about this).
  • The audience was time constrained but would be willing to self report whether they ate healthy or not if it was simple
  • They had a wearable device or would be willing to purchase one so we could passively aggregate their data and “score” their progress

Step Three: Market Assumptions

Potential customers must get involved to make sure there’s interest and need in the product. Avoiding customers’ input would lead to more work, more cost and...well...fat methodology. And no one wants that.

So after some general assumptions were made, we set off to test their validity. We posted a simple five-question survey to all the forum members and Facebook followers of the Primal Blueprint. We received 19 completed surveys. Of those, 14 said they were either enthusiastic or very enthusiastic about the product and 12 said they either had a wearable device or would be willing to purchase one.

Based on our limited time, we made the assumption that a larger sample would prove the same results (normally one would perform a much more extensive set of market research to improve confidence). We also knew that over 250k copies of the Primal Blueprint had been sold and they had over 50k subscribers on their forum. There was a large enough audience that had the problem to make it worthwhile to solve. Three of our assumptions had passed enough to take the next steps but one did not. Out of the 14 respondents, 70% were age 30-45, female-leaning parents who lived in metropolitan areas. Our initial assumption was age 22-30, male-leaning, recent college graduates living in metropolitan areas. We stuck with the assumption that they were Achiever Intellectual archetype.

Redefining our assumptions about our audience based on what we learned from our product discovery phase affected our branding and some functionality of the final prototype. Had we not performed the discovery process and implemented lean methodology, we may have focused on a less engaged audience and wouldn’t know what they needed or wanted. Ultimately, this would have decreased our likelihood for success.

Key Takeaways:

  • Start by figuring out the problem that needs to be solved and then develop a minimum viable product (MVP) to begin the process of learning as quickly as possible.
  • Make assumptions about what your customers’ wants and needs are.
  • Get their feedback.

Next month, I’ll be expanding on the lean startup method and the next steps in designing and developing with this in mind. The real test is after the initial prototype is built, will people actually engage with it and how much? More on this to come...

Read more about what makes a mobile health app effective.
summary: The discovery phase of the product development process is critical for uncovering the “real” problems that need to be solved. It’s also important in helping define the initial target audience or user base.
title: Leveraging the Lean Startup Methodology to Build Software

In my never-ending quest to try to understand everything about everything, I eventually had to figure out how scheduling mechanisms (Threads) work within Cocoa (the framework for Mac OSX & iOS Development). It isn’t as simple as you’d think. For example, a thread can be spawned and given an associated task which will be completed from start-to-finish. However, what about portions of your task that need to wait for a response before it can proceed further? What do you do with those? In circumstances like these, Apple has included an event-processing mechanism called a “Run Loop”, which simplifies the amount of work a programmer needs to do to account for event-driven code.

I previously wrote a post about building an asynchronous networking library. This article will dive even further into an important part of what makes it work, “Run Loops”, which are integral to performing asynchronous tasks.

So, first, what is a run loop? Apple’s documentation says:

“Run loops are part of the fundamental infrastructure associated with threads. A run loop is an event processing loop that you use to schedule work and coordinate the receipt of incoming events. The purpose of a run loop is to keep your thread busy when there is work to do and put your thread to sleep when there is none.” -Threading Programming Guide: “Run Loops”, Apple Inc.

So, let’s explore this a little further: A “thread” (for those of you reading this who don’t know) is a scheduling mechanism for queueing tasks to be processed by the CPU. These threads are managed by the operating system’s “scheduler”, and given a place in line where they are eventually executed. In the context of a multiprocessor environment, you can execute threads “concurrently” (at the same time). This allows software to perform certain time-consuming tasks in the background without slowing down the responsiveness of the user interface (what we call performing a task “asynchronously”).

There can be some hurdles while performing tasks asynchronously (namely, the synchronization, “re-coupling”, of data), but this is a topic that can be discussed at-length in another article. For now, let’s jump back to how run loops fit in.

In Cocoa and Cocoa-Touch development, run loops are the mechanism you will utilize to make sure your event-driven, asynchronous task properly responds to any activity that occurs during the lifespan of the thread it is operating within. If the events for the task are not allowed to occur, and aren’t responded to, you risk not acquiring, or utilizing, the data you need to complete the intent of the task. Below is a sample class diagram for the structure of a threaded, asynchronous task:

  • Thread (this can be spawned using NSThread, Grand-Central Dispatch, NSOperation, or “performSelectorInBackground:”)
  • NSRunLoop/Task
  • Event-Driven Object (this is a class whose functionality requires time to process in order for events associated with it to occur. An example would be a running NSURLConnection object, or a socket)

As you can see from above, the order of encapsulation begins with a thread, continues up the stack with the NSRunLoop and Task associated with it, and then finally into the context of the object which is utilizing the RunLoop. This dependency makes sure that the task has both its own space to operate, and the means to make sure its instructions are fully carried out.

To schedule your event-driven object/class within a run loop be sure to call the method below:

 [<object/class> scheduleInRunLoop:[NSRunLoop currentRunLoop] forMode: NSRunLoopCommonModes];

Simply scheduling the event-driven object (within your task) inside the current thread’s run loop isn’t enough. You have to tell the run loop when to start polling for events. This can be done with:

 [[NSRunLoop currentRunLoop] run];

or

 [[NSRunLoop currentRunLoop] runMode:NSRunLoopCommonModes beforeDate:<a Date>];

or

 [[NSRunLoop currentRunLoop] runUntilDate:<a Date>];

Keep in mind that once you begin running the run loop, events/methods will only fire if they are included within the scope of that method call. Thus, if this portion of your task is written as:

 [runLoop "run" method call];
[another method call];

The following method will never get called while the run loop is running. Whereas if the task is written as:

 [a local method call];
[runLoop "run" method call];

The method within the scope of the run loop’s “run” method call will be performed during the run loop’s duration. This is important if you wish to manually exit the thread via some kind of “time-out” mechanism (usually implemented through a timer, or “NSTimer”, in this case).

If implemented correctly you should be able to witness your application’s responsiveness during asynchronously-performed tasks (via the class’ delegate methods, or whatever “Observer” pattern you’ve implemented). Congratulations!

Be sure to check out Apple’s “Threading Programming Guide” for future reference, or if you have any issues.

As always, good luck with your implementation of multi-threaded design! Don’t hesitate to drop me a line if you have any comments or questions. See you next time!

body:
Hutto, Yardi, and Gilbert (2013) recently released a study containing data social media nerds have wanted for years. Not just any data mind you but Twitter data, the social media holy grail. The study A Longitudinal Study of Follow Predictors on Twitter examines how social behavior, message content, and network structure influence follower growth. The Georgia Institute of Technology and University of Michigan researchers’ greatest analytical tool is the longitudinal nature of their study. The ability to measure follower growth over 15 months allows the data to suggest a causal relationship between the predictor variables and follower growth.

Of the behavioral and social variables found in Hutto et al. (2013) one notable finding involves the negative effect of broadcast communications on follower growth. Broadcast communications are messages not directed at a specific user or group of users. That is, using Twitter as a bulletin board as opposed to a mode of dyadic (two-way) communication will constrain your number of followers. In turn, directed communications (e.g. replies, ‘@’ mentions, and favorites directed at someone else) have a positive effect on follower growth. Even so, the positive influence of directed communications is not as strong as the negative effect of broadcast communications. Twitter is a conversation platform, evidenced by the marked differences in the effects of communication types on follower growth. Engagement on a one-to-one level between users is the great benefit of social media, why wouldn’t you harness that?


Researchers also found that expressing negativity is the second most important factor in stunting follower growth. While talking smack may be a treasured pasttime for close friend groups, the relatively weak relationships found on Twitter makes spewing virtual venom a big no-no. Want to further alienate potential new-followers? Use too many hashtags. The median ratio of hashtags per Tweet during the recorded periods was .13. Respect the power of the tag, if you’re using more than one-two hashtags per 10 Tweets, you’re  doing too much.

Rest assured that message content variables were not all doom and gloom. Both spreading informational content and writing Tweets worth retweeting were significant predictors of growth. Hutto et al. (2013) define informational content as Tweets containing a URL, “RT”, “MT”, “HT”, or “via” (MT meaning modified Tweet and HT meaning heard through). Unfortunately, the researchers do not provide a formula for creating top Tweets, though being re-elected President apparently helps.

While the follower counts of Twitter’s informer class are likely to grow, the platform’s more self obsessed users, or “meformers” are not as lucky. Although users were found to Tweet about themselves more often (41% “meformer” compared to 26% “informer”), informational content is 30 times more effective in attracting new followers. Yes, 30 times. So try and avoid the “humblebrag”. Also, start dropping knowledge or RTing, because new potential followers won’t care about your self-referential blathering.

@JoeMande I'm gonna go ahead and call #tthb(triple threat humble brag)

— Chelsea Peretti (@ChelseaVPeretti) October 6, 2010

Thanks to Joe Mande and Chelsea Peretti respectively, for demonstrating a proper #humblebrag and an appropriate public shaming for doing so.

While Hutto el al. (2013) spent relatively less ink discussing the effect of network structure on follower growth, the researchers did communicate that greater network overlap between a user and their current followers increases the likelihood of a user attracting new followers. Part of the influence of network overlap (i.e. the number of neighbors users have in common) on follower growth may be associated with the idea of triadic closure. If my follower (B) RTs me (A), and my follower’s follower (X) views and likes the content of that RT, my follower’s follower (X) is more likely to follow me (A). The potential for X to follow A grows the more X is exposed to positive or informational content by A. If multiple users which A and X have in common spread content produced by A, the potential for X to follow A increases. According to Hutto et al. the relationship between A, B, and X achieves “cognitive balance” when all three are connected.

The relatively simple calculations of users’ in-link reciprocity and attention status can alert users whether they need to adjust aspects of their social media strategy. In-link reciprocity is a ratio of a user’s followers, specifically which of their followers a user follows in return. The attention-status ratio is the proportion of a user’s followers to the accounts a user is following. So, in-link reciprocity [User's Followers: User Follows/Follows User] and attention status [Follows User /User Follows] were significant predictors of follower growth with medians of .25 and 1.19 respectively.


Without unpacking the statistical explanation for why higher attention status and in-link reciprocity ratios predict follower growth, I’ll offer my understanding as a relative layperson. Both ratios signal the symmetry, or asymmetry of the relationships between Twitter users. As noted in Golder and Yardi (2010) attention is a limited resource. The very notion of popularity is that more people are aware of the popular individual than he or she can attend to on a regular basis. When applied to Twitter, the higher the ratio of followers a user has compared to accounts they follow (attention-status ratio), the more popular the individual. Based on the research of Hutto et al., the higher a user’s attention-status ratio the greater the likelihood a user will attract new followers. The lesson: popular kids will continue to grow in popularity by virtue of being popular, it’s like high school never ended. However, if a user follows their new followers, the potential for attracting new followers increases as well.

Golder and Yardi compare the reciprocal nature of following one’s followers as akin to repaying a favor. Through repaying follows, users can solidify social media’s relatively weak bonds and protect themselves against the dreaded unfollowing. Be mindful however, that increases in attention status ratio have a greater effect on attracting new followers than increasing in-link reciprocity. In other terms, have more followers than friends.

Twitter’s influence can hardly be confined to data sets. Fortunately, how we interact with each other on the platform is more quantifiable as evidenced in the research of Hutto et al. If you want a quick list of tips for increasing your Twitter followers, look at this article or maybe this one. But instead of taking the path of numbered lists, read the original research elaborating on the network structure variables. The well worn trope about being an informed consumer, well, it’s more than a figure of speech especially as Twitter is concerned. In a relatively short amount of time, mastery of 140 characters or less became an influential manner of gaining social capital. Individuals unknown before 2006 have the opportunity to become “micro-celebrities”, and both established and up-and-coming brands have access to a less expensive marketing channel.

If you’re not Tweeting, review the research and start. If you’re already thousands of Tweets deep into the platform, use the research to refine your technique. Also, follow Smashing Boxes on Twitter @SmashingBoxes and continue the discussion on how to best increase follower growth.

Take a look at our work.

In the early 90s we experienced a revolution in desktop publishing and were on the cusp of changing the way people shared information and communicated. I was a sophomore in high school and was a member of our newspaper. At the time, I was learning Adobe PageMaker and thought, “wouldn’t it be cool to move from cut and paste on a light table to running our design and production from my Mac?” I convinced our teacher to get us a few Macintosh SEs to help innovate our process. Switching to desktop publishing helped us grow from a bi-monthly newspaper to a monthly newsmagazine and reduced costs significantly. It was my first foray into understanding how software and technology could help drive innovation.

Fast forward twenty years…as the cofounder of two software start-ups I learned quickly that you could end up running on fumes if you don’t pace your development resources well. As a domain expert in the health and exercise sciences, I didn’t always have enough programming acumen to communicate my vision and users’ needs to our developers. I was also handicapped when meeting with potential customers who had a technical team with questions regarding integration and additional features. It required me to bring a developer to the conversation to field questions and help us understand the potential knots and opportunities.

Enter Code School

When I shared with friends and family that I was considering immersing myself in code for 12-weeks I received some pretty interesting looks…mostly confused. The underlying theme was, “why the heck do you need to learn to write code…can’t you just hire developers?”

This is a good question. I would argue that the landscape of entrepreneurship and product development for startups and early stage software companies is changing. Those that lack the technical acumen to communicate with their development team and potential clients and the ability to prototype ideas before even hiring talent are at a disadvantage.

This isn’t to say that you have to be able to develop robust, fully functioning, bug-free applications using test-driven development. You should, however, be able to understand what your developers are talking about when creating your MVP or adding additional features. This can help bring your product to market more quickly and your development team will probably respect the fact that you understand the product and constraints from their lens and not expect the world in the first release.

I didn't enter code school for the same reason many others do. My ambition was not to become a full time developer or programmer. I wanted to gain enough expertise to prototype basic applications and communicate more effectively with developers. The goal was to improve my ability to help design simple but elegant products that solve big problems.

My Experience

A little over twelve weeks ago I started code school in Durham, NC. It was not unlike the first few months of getting a start up off the ground, intense and exhausting, but with some key differences.

Building a technology “startup” is like being the head coach of a football team. You are constantly leading, designing, managing, strategizing and selling. You’re supported but alone at the same time.

Code school, is more like trying to set a personal record in a 10k…you start out setting a fast pace making up as much ground as you can. Then you back off a bit, knowing if you maintain that pace you may crack. Finally, you try to pick it up at the end when the finish line is in sight. All the while there are people supporting you (family, classmates and community).

The first month was by far the most challenging. Eighty to one hundred hour weeks were expected if you wanted to keep up. At the end of 10 weeks of learning and hammering out code, we were given two weeks to produce a final product. I was lucky enough to be partnered with two talented developers and we designed a fully functioning app named Pladel (a mobile application that provides one simple score to measure your health and takes the guesswork out of what to eat). We all agreed that if we had it to do over we would have ripped out most of the ruby code and served an API from a Rails framework and built the front end using either Angular or Ember (two front-end frameworks) to give us more flexibility. I mention this because that is one of the things you learn in code school…how to understand what to build more efficiently to create better customer experiences and ultimately a more scalable business.

Just like learning to use Adobe PageMaker to rough out our layout for my high school newspaper helped me better communicate with my designer, my ability to code is now allowing me to prototype apps and communicate more effectively with developers. This has been a significant asset in my new role helping start ups to Fortune 100 companies innovate great products and services at Smashing Boxes.

If you have any questions or are thinking about going to code school, don’t hesitate to connect with me. I’m happy to share more about my experience…it was exhausting but very rewarding and all the training paid off.

Get the FAQs on code school here.

This week is Computer Science Education Week and even President Obama is helping out with the Hour of Code initiative. We know that a lot of people are thinking about trying to learn how to code (which is totally awesome). It is definitely not too late for anyone to learn, but most people have no idea where to even start. If this sounds familiar, this is the post for you. Since everyone needs a website or has an app idea, the focus of this post is on programming languages that can be used for web or mobile app development

First, what is front-end vs. back-end development? Front-end web development describes the visual, user-friendly layer of the website that the user interacts with and is used to collect inputs. Back-end web development uses the inputs that come from the front-end and is composed of servers, applications, and databases. Information is stored by the application in the database, which lives on the server. Mobile development incorporates both front- and back-end development components, but is mostly front-end.

A great analogy from a General Assembly front-end developer explains that if a website is a car, then the internal components of the car that you can’t see, but that make it run would be the back-end, and the things you can touch/use/hear to make the car move or that make it cool/fun are the front-end.

Let’s dive in to the fun part, what are the best tutorials to use to learn how to code?

Front-end Development Languages

HTML/CSS

HTML and Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) are used to make websites pretty. You can’t go wrong with learning HTML because every website builds upon HTML elements, which define document elements (e.g. headers, titles, paragraphs). CSS deals with the presentation (e.g. layout, color, and font) of the page.

body:
Last month, we introduced you to the practice and service that is Growth Engineering. What we didn’t tell you is that Google Analytics is a HUGE component of growth engineering. While you don’t have to be GA certified to be in this industry, it definitely helps. And to become certified, you have to take the Google Analytics Individual Qualification (GAIQ) Exam. So, this is where I come in.

You may have heard the GAIQ Exam can be pretty difficult to pass. Well Google released an updated version of the test in January 2014 and along with it came a whole slew of new questions, new answers and more confusing verbiage. Awesome!

If you were anything like me when I was first preparing for it, you’re probably in the process of trying to find out as much information as possible about the test before taking the plunge. When I took the test, I was a little nervous about taking it because I am a terrible test taker. I read every article, blog post, and forum I could find that mentioned the test, and some were helpful and some not so much. But I passed on my first time taking it and now want to pass on my (study tips) onto you. In this post I will address the test format, study resources, and test tips. Hopefully this resource will save you some time and stress and point you in the right direction before you take it.

Test Format

Quick facts about the GAIQ:

  • Costs $50 to take
  • 70 multiple-choice questions
  • 90-minute time limit (you can pause the test as many times as you like, but the time expires five days after starting it)
  • It is an open book test (don’t be misled; this doesn’t make it much easier)
  • 80% is the passing score (you can’t miss more than 14 questions)
  • You receive a certificate and your name appears in Google’s database of Qualified Individuals (you can look me up!)
  • Certification expires after 18 months (and then we get to start this whole process over, WOO!)

You’ll pay and take the test in Google’s Testing Center. If you get below an 80% you will have to wait 15 days before you can try again. However, after the test (pass or fail) Google will provide you with areas you need to improve upon.

Study Resources

I want to offer you my three “must study” resources:

  1. Google’s Analytics Academy is the first place you should start. I believe this was once called Conversion University (so if you see other blogs telling you to use CU just know they are the same thing). Google’s Analytics Advocate, Justin Cutroni, walks you through an overview of Google Analytics in the Digital Analytics Fundamentals course. Personally, I think this is the best resource because the videos are easy to understand and there are assessments after each lesson.

Resource Tip: Each lesson has a text version. I downloaded those and made a PDF pseudo-textbook for the test. This will cut down on searching for the answer to a tricky question.

- They now have more lessons with assessments that focus more attention on subjects covered in the fundamentals course, e.g. Ecommerce

2. Once you complete the free course and the final assessment, you should check out this Google Analytics Practice Test. The practice test has more than 200 practice questions and you can pick what topics you want to study, e.g. Goals & Funnels or Internal Site Search. It was developed by Eric Fettman; the man is a Google Analytics genius. Many say that the practice test is harder than the actual test and I would have to agree. It reinforces your knowledge and shows what you may need to study more before taking the real test. Definitely check it out.

3. If you are not a fan of watching videos and would rather read to obtain this knowledge, you should check out Jens Sorensen’s analytics blog post. But be prepared, it is packed full of information and is extremely lengthy for a blog post. Also fair warning, he wrote this post in 2010 and while still a very good resource, Google has removed some of the topics that you will see on the test (e.g. _utmv cookie).

I strongly urge you to check out/do these first before attempting to take the test. I found that cheat sheets were great for finding answers quickly and printed them out to have in front of me during the test:

  • Blast Handy Google Analytics Reference Guide
  • Portent Interactive Google Analytics Cheat Sheet 2

If you’re brave you can try taking the test with just these. But I suggest that you study the first three resources.

Test Tips:

  1. Practice If you don’t have a Google Analytics account, you need to make one. This will allow you to play around with the interfaces and it will give you a better understanding of the lessons. It also is great to have open during the test as a reference.
  2. Know the types of Questions What stressed me out most about the test was that I didn’t know what the format of the questions were going to be like. In all the resources I found, they mentioned that the questions are multiple choice but never gave more detail as to exactly what type of multiple choice questions they are (single answer? multiple answer? all of the above?, WHAT?!). In the course and practice test there were a lot of “Select all that apply” multiple choice questions. Well, I hate to say it, but they’re also on the real test. The test questions vary between true/false, single answer, and select all that apply. Additionally, there are either four or five answer choices for each question.
  3. Pay attention to time You have 90 minutes to complete the test, and the countdown clock in the top right corner of the test window doesn’t let you forget it. You have about a minute and thirty seconds for each question. No pressure, right? However, the pause button is the saving grace. If you get stumped you can pause the test, which will blur out the question and you scan through your resources to find the answer. If you rather not pause the test and continue trucking through you can mark questions you’re not sure of. There is a scrolling list of questions on the right side of the window and you can easily navigate back to the marked ones.
  4. Open Resources Since the test is open book, you can have all your handy resources open in other windows/tabs. I had these three open while taking the test: Google Analytics Configuration Tool, URL Builder, and Google’s Analytics Help Center. Some other blogs say to have an easy RegEx (Regular Expression) generator open. I didn’t have any RegEx questions, but better safe than sorry.

If I missed something that you were looking for you may want to check out these other resources about the test:

Google Analytics Certification and How to Pass the GAIQ Test - Fantastic general guide for the GAIQ test it also has a practice test questions that you can download.

GAIQ Study Sheet - This is an older study sheet but it still has a lot topics that the GAIQ covers.

How to Pass the Google Analytics IQ Test in Two Days: Zero to Hero - Great resource guide for the GAIQ especially if you’re trying to pass quickly.

The Complete Guide to studying for the Google Analytics IQ Exam - Awesome guide for studying and has great advice from experts.

Hopefully this has given you a better understanding or confidence about the test. Now go practice! If you have any additional questions about the test, I would love to help, so feel free to leave a comment below.

Read more about the essentials of Google Analytics here.
summary: Last month, we introduced you to the practice and service that is Growth Engineering. What we didn’t tell you is that Google Analytics is a HUGE component of growth engineering. While you don’t have to be GA certified to be in this industry, it definitely helps. And to become certified, you have to take the Google Analytics Individual Qualification (GAIQ) Exam. So, this is where I come in.
title: Tips for Passing the 2014 Google Analytics Exam

body:
In my previous article right after WWDC14, I compared Swift to Objective-C. We received some very good feedback but one question in particular really caught my attention: “Would anyone recommend learning Swift or start with Objective-C first? I feel that learning C would give me a better understanding of the internal workings and will lead to better code, but it will take much more time and has a steeper learning curve.”

To answer this question and perhaps the question of many potential iOS developers, I feel that it would be better to start off learning Objective-C before Swift. Let me explain my reasoning.

Obj-C is an established language. It made its appearance in 1983 making it a little over 30 years old! While Swift may look great it is continuing to evolve and mature over time. Apple’s App Store contains over 1.2 million apps to download and most all of these apps are written in Obj-C. If someone were trying to break into the iOS development industry, hiring managers will be looking for development experience in Obj-C to help maintain their existing apps. It will take time for the majority of iOS developers to completely switch to using Swift for iOS development.

Because Obj-C has been around for so long, you will find that most of the iOS development related questions asked on sites such as StackOverflow are answered with Obj-C code. Many tutorials are also written using Obj-C. Some well-known tutorial sites like Ray Wenderlich.com are moving to use only Swift for future content which is great, but all the past tutorials are written in Obj-C.

You will learn Obj-C a lot faster, and after gaining a good understanding of it, learning Swift will be a piece of cake. Swift contains a lot of modern features that will make it more versatile, more concise, and nicer to read and write, but it’s still in its infancy. For the next several years, it will be important for professional iOS developers to have a good grasp of both Objective-C and Swift. One could definitely understand Swift without a good grip on Obj-C but if starting out with iOS development it's better to start with Obj-C. Since Obj-C is a completely different language than Swift it's not required to know, it but if you are thinking about getting into iOS development, it is definitely recommended to learn first. Once you’re familiar with the iOS patterns used to develop apps, you can use exactly the same patterns while writing in both languages, so moving from one language to the other is just a matter of learning the syntax. With Swift, you’re developing apps using the same framework and APIs as you would with Obj-C. I have found that after getting the syntax down, it becomes very simple to write the functionality you want for your app.

Initializing a UIView with size 200x200 and a blue background:

Keep in mind this is just my opinion, but it’s definitely worth researching both languages and eventually using both for better app development.

There are lots of options for learning Obj-C on your own. These are some of my favorites:

Apple’s Programming with Objective-C

Code School

Big Nerd Ranch Objective-C programming book

Cover photo from "The story of the sun, moon, and stars" (1898)
summary: Smashing Boxes mobile developer Jordan Clifton gives his insights on using Objective-C first over Apple's Swift.
title: Apple’s Swift: Should Beginners Still Learn Objective-C?

body:
What are Single Page Applications?

Single page applications (SPAs) are applications that break away from traditional page rendering methods. They provide a snappier experience for users when compared to traditional static and server rendered pages.

In the traditional method of rendering a webpage, a backend server builds or retrieves an HTML file and sends the entire file to the browser in one action. If the user wishes to perform another action, such as going from the search bar to the search results page, the browser loads an entirely new page. This works fine and is the model that most of the Web still follows today. Single page applications promise to provide users with a richer experience than possible with this traditional model.

Single page client side applications load similarly to traditional web pages. Rather than reload new pages for every user action, however, a single page app will load data in the background and seamlessly repaint the current page, giving the user a sense of instant feedback not possible with traditional web pages. The end effect is faster response times and an experience that feels more like a native app than a web page. The user is never forced to stare at a blank screen, and some data can even be loaded preemptively, before the user performs an action.

Slow Apps Kill Your Conversion Rate

Slow pages frustrate users. This leads to higher rates of page abandonment and destroys your organization’s conversion rate. Some studies have shown that even a one second waiting period will drive your conversion rate down by as much as 7%. Slow pages are not just an issue for your IT department - they can have a negative effect on your bottom line.

Are They A Good Fit?

Despite benefits gained by creating SPAs, they can add a level of complexity to the development process. For certain types of websites, particularly those that perform simple information retrieval tasks, the benefits of creating a single page application may be less apparent.

Some of the most common concerns that an organization will need to address when building a new single application are:

  • Search engine optimization and discoverability

  • Accessibility

  • Outdated browser support

  • Internationalization and foreign language support (i18n)

  • Link sharing and bookmarks

All of the concerns listed can be fixed by a knowledgeable software engineer, but they are issues that should be addressed as early as possible in the development cycle.

It may also be worth considering whether a single page application is the correct approach for the particular problem your organization wishes to solve.

Some good questions to ask are:

  • Is the application focused on manipulation of data and user interaction, or is it simply performing retrieval of stored information?

  • Is the site a true 'application', or is it focused on presenting information that will rarely change eg. “brochureware”?

  • Will the application ever need to tie into third party services or provide an alternative means of access, such as a mobile client?

It’s More Than Just Speed

There are a number of other reasons that you may wish to consider a single page approach. Most notable is the ability to provide realtime app feedback in the browser such as real time streaming updates, infinitely scrollable search results, and offline-first web apps that can operate without an Internet connection.

Aside from speed and a larger range of features, SPAs offer a huge win for long-term maintainability. This is because single page applications typically follow a service-based architecture that separates data access concerns (an API) from the user interface. As an example, a web-based version of the application and a native mobile app can share the same data via an API. This turns into cost savings when services can be reused without modification. Splitting an application into services also means that changes to client application code have no effect on API or infrastructure level applications and vice versa.

Take a Look

Smashing Boxes has built a variety of web and mobile applications that take advantage of many of these principles. Take a look at some of our past work or our Github. Stay tuned for our next article which will cover a high level technical overview of the architecture of single page applications.

In my previous post, I discussed how Google Tag Manager (GTM) will save you and your developers time tracking events on your website. Tracking events provides valuable insights into user interactions with specific elements on your site. These insights can be used to evaluate user behavior, assess whether users are behaving as expected, and develop ideas for testing if the behavior is unexpected. Using the same PDF download tracking example as before, we’ll now take a deeper look into how GTM works and the setup involved in creating a tag.

To do this, we’re going to track this generic PDF button that has a link to our 2014 Widgets PDF.

Let’s assume that you have created a GTM container and already placed it immediately after the '< body >' tag of your site. When we first open our GTM container we will see that we have no tags in it. Perfect, this means we have a clean working environment and have freedom to create new tags.

The first tag that we are going to make is a Link Listener. This Tag is going to listen for any clicks that happen on the page. To create a Tag, click on the New button and select Tag.

First, we need to name our Tag and in this case we’re going to write “Example Link Listener.” Be sure to label anything you create in GTM clearly so that other users know what the Tag does or is tracking.

After you enter a clearly defined name, click on the Tag Type drop down menu. It will open up a long list of Tag Types. Maneuver your mouse down to Event Listener and select the Link Click Listener.

Great, we have just created our first tag but we are not finished quite yet. In the top right corner you will see Firing Rules. This is actually what causes the Tag to be fired.

We are going to add our first Rule to our Link Listener Tag. Luckily, Google has predefined the rule we will be using for our Link Listener Tag. The All Pages Rule means this Tag will fire on all of our web pages. Once we have saved this rule on on Link Listener we can move on to our next Tag, an Event Tag.

We want to select Create New Tag and make sure it is labeled clearly. In this example we’ve named it, “Example PDF Download.” This time we are going to hover over the Google Analytics tab and select Universal Analytics. (If you are not running Universal Analytics you need to select Classic.)

Once Universal Analytics is selected, scroll down and enter your Google Analytics Tracking Code ID. This is UA-XXXXXXX in your Google Analytics account and is what links your tag info to your events reports.

Note: If you create a {{GA Tracking Code}} macro then you don’t have to enter your ID in each time you make a new event tag. Check out GTM expert Simo Ahava’s post to see how to do this.

Once you have typed your GA ID into the text field, scroll down till you see the Track Type drop down selector. It will have pageview selected as the default but we are going to edit that field.

Select Event as what we want to track. This will open up four text fields under Event Tracking Parameters. As I mentioned earlier, we’re going to use the same Category, Action, and Label from my earlier post. If you aren’t sure what these are or what role they play in Google Analytics, stop here and read the post on Event Tracking.

Now that we have typed PDF_Downloads and Download in the Category and Action fields. But in the label field there this {{element id}} macro. This is a macro, which will return the ID that is associated with our PDF button. In this case it will return “2014_widgets_pdf” in our Google Analytics Events Report as the Event Label.

This Tag is ready to go, but we have one small problem with it. We need a rule that will cause this Tag to fire when people click on it. To do this, we must connect our “Example Link Listener” Tag to our “Example PDF Download” Tag. The rule for our “Example PDF Download” Tag is going to be named “Example PDF Download Rule.” This will be a little trickier because Google has not predefined it for us.

Okay that’s a lot, so let’s press pause for a moment. I’m going briefly to tell you about an amazing Google Chrome extension that Simo Ahava developed called GTM Sonar. I highly suggest you download it. Once you turn it on, you’ll select what listener you are planning to use for your Tag, in our case you should select Link Listener.

Click on the PDF button on your site. Open up your browser Console, type in debugDL and press enter. It will return an Object with all the pertinent GTM information you need for your rule that will cause your tag to fire.

Back to our “Example PDF Download Rule.” We can now enter the information from our console to make the rule work. For the PDF Download Tag to fire the event must contain a gtm.linkClick, which it does. We want the Tag to fire if the element class contains “button” in the class. And just in case other buttons have the same class name we want the element ID to contain “PDF” in it. If any of those parameters are false, the Tag will not fire.

Click save and you will see your Tags in the container draft. Before you publish this draft in your container you should Preview and Debug your tags on your site to make sure your Tags are firing correctly.

This is a very simple example of how to use GTM. Many times it is not as straightforward as this. For example, many developers do not like using IDs in their code, in which case you will need to find another way to get the name of the specific PDF a user downloaded in your Label field. In such instances we would use the element url or {{element url}} macro to return different labels.

I hope this post has helped you with the complexities of Event Tagging and GTM. On Google+ or LinkedIn? Follow us +SmashingBoxes and join us on LinkedIn to get updates on more articles like this.

The Problem:

As a general rule, you don’t see event-based audio in the browser, or at least not outside of some embedded flash object or popup ad. Gone are the days when you’d hear that crisp IE “click” sound every time you clicked a link. No more do we jump for the volume controls when we mistakenly navigate to a page with a MIDI rendition of “Eye of the Tiger” set to auto play in the background. Most sites don’t even set embedded videos to start automatically. You can see why the question of how best to implement it doesn’t come up very often.

A recent client project centered around gamifying the college entrance process called for event-driven audio in some of the interactive activities. This is one of the few contexts where I would argue audio events have a place. Music and sound effects play a big role in conveying information about the game state to the player. Still, building games in the browser with native code remains a touchy process, and the more browsers you try to support the touchier it gets. In this case, we wanted it all. Everything from iPad to IE8 had to provide the same interactive experience.

Normally the obvious option would be to throw one of the myriad Flash-based audio players on the page and be done with it, but the iPad can’t stomach Flash. Besides, we like to live on the bleeding edge here and I didn’t want to submit to the <embed> tag unless it was the only option.

The HTML5 <audio> element is still messy at best. Browser audio APIs are improving and moving towards a unified spec but the chart of compatible formats still reads like a pick-three of audio file extensions, with no two browsers picking the same three.

What’s Out There:

In doing research for this project I came across a lot of tutorials, snippets and plugins that claimed to allow you to use the <audio> tag with impunity. Almost all of these were built using multiple file formats for each audio file and a Flash fallback for older browsers. Most were also meant to be used for embedding songs, podcasts and the like. Of the ones I tested out, the simplest implementations didn’t provide a way to control the player programmatically and the more complex packages took a lot of configuration and had a lot of moving pieces.

The Flash fallback route was really the only option for supporting such a wide range of browsers but I wanted a middle-of-the-road solution that would bark on command but wouldn’t attempt to manage my entire MP3 collection for me. Enter audio.js.

The audio.js package consists of four files:

  • audio.min.js
  • audiojs.swf
  • player-graphics.gif
  • index.css

It’s lightweight to say the least and was the quickest to get up and running. It works by creating a JavaScript wrapper around the <audio> element that handles all browser discrepancies and allows you to use code like this:

<audio src="/mp3/juicy.mp3" preload="auto" />

For browsers without <audio> support of some kind, it defaults to the Flash player as expected, but the UI is all built with HTML and CSS and updated via JavaScript, so the user will see the same player no matter what their browser supports. Player appearance was admittedly not the biggest issue here since it would be hidden most of the time but it was one less thing to worry about.

What about browser support? The audio.js site claims

  • Mobile Safari (iOS 3+)
  • Android (2.2+, w/Flash)
  • Safari (4+)
  • Chrome (7+)
  • Firefox (3+, w/ Flash)
  • Opera (10+, w/ Flash)
  • IE (6, 7, 8, w/ Flash)

An impressive list given the API fragmentation. Flash is listed as caveat more often than not but with JavaScript hooks to control the player instance I didn’t have to worry about what type of player  was being loaded in order to play a file.

It was love on $(document).ready(). But that doesn’t mean we didn’t have our occasional fights. It took me a little while to get my head around the available methods because there is no detailed documentation available (however, the annotated source is clean and concise). When testing in IE, I was plagued with an “Object doesn’t support this property or method” error for a while that had to do with how I was procedurally loading the audio files. A few hurdles, but nothing to put me off for good.

There may be better audio solutions out there but this is one of the simplest and most functional I’ve seen. It plays the audio by hook or by crook with minimal markup and access to player controls in JavaScript when needed. audio.js is definitely going in the resources folder for now.

Ruby on Rails makes web application development easier by favoring convention over configuration. Its creators say it is optimized for programmer happiness, and lets us focus on the client's needs rather than the common tasks/chores involved in building every web application. Outside of "The Rails Way," many other alternatives exist, so we decided to explore one of them.

Introducing: The Clean Architecture Template

Awhile back, I wrote about domain logic in Rails and promised a follow-up with an example. I decided rather than simply providing an example app, I'd rather have a template for generating them so it would be easy to create many apps and hopefully get feedback and contributions from the community. I've started working on a Rails template which you can fork on Github and will describe briefly what I've done here.

The Rails Template

Rails has a basic, but quite usable, API for app creation. The blog post, Rails Application Templates, by Dave Copeland of Stitch Fix was of enormous help in getting me started writing a Rails template. For now, I want to keep it fairly standard and familiar for Rails developers to use, so I kept the directory structure intact. The major changes include:

  • Completely change the Gemfile by removing unnecessary gems such as jbuilder, sqlite, and sdoc and adding gems like hashie, pg, and tilt. These choices are debatable of course, but in keeping with the opinionated nature of Rails, I decided to pick these defaults.
    • Hashie is a collection of Hash extensions that work very well for creating data objects to be passed between interactors and views.
    • The pg gem is included simply because I feel PostgreSQL is the right way to begin a project.
    • Tilt is a gem that will hopefully enable sharing views between Rails and Javascript frameworks. Tilt enables multiple templating engines, including Handlebars, which is widely supported among Javascript frameworks. This aspect of Clean Architecture is still experimental as I describe below.
  • Create two new generators, one for entities and one for interactors. These are invoked just like Rails standard generators (e.g. "rails generate entity name"). They also generate a spec file in spec/entities/name_spec.rb.
  • Added a spec_helper.rb and provided some shared examples for entities and interactors.
  • Revamp the controller generator to create the type of controller actions that are common to Clean Architecture-style apps. See the example below.
  • TODO: create generators for repositories and Handlebars templates.

Clean Controllers

class UsersController < ApplicationController
  respond_to :html
  before_filter :authenticate_user!
  def user_params
    params.require(:user).permit :first_name, :last_name, :email, :password, :password_confirmation, :phone
  end
  private :user_params
  def index
    @response = BrowseUsers.new(@request).call.extend(UserPresenter)
    respond_with @response
  end
  def show
    @response = LoadUser.new(@request).call
    respond_with @response
  end
  alias_method :edit, :show
  def new
    @response = NewUser.new(@request).call
    respond_with @response
  end
  def create
    @request.object_attributes = user_params
    @response = SaveUser.new(@request).call
    respond_with @response.user, location: users_path
  end
  alias_method :update, :create
  def destroy
    @response = DeleteUser.new(@request).call
    respond_with @response, location: users_path
  end
end

Use the generator like so: rails generate controller users index show new create destroy It will work in much the same way as the controller I posted previously:

The generator also adds rendering code that uses tilt-handlebars to render a template that can be shared between back-end and front-end.

Decoupling UI from the Use Cases

In keeping with the theme of writing clean, decoupled code, I decided to root out the rendering portions of Rails by calling the Rails app generator with the following options: --skip-action-view --skip-sprockets --skip-javascript

What does this mean for developers? The front-end is now completely decoupled from the back-end. Front-end developers are free to use their preferred tools such as Bower and Gulp to manage dependencies and front-end builds. Back-end developers are now free to focus entirely on the API without having to worry about finding up-to-date gems for their front-end framework of choice. Even full-stack developers who handle both front and back-end will benefit from the increased manageability and testability of the decoupled code.

What Needs to be Done

Obviously this is not a complete framework or example for creating Rails apps according to the Clean Architecture pattern, but I hope it can at least spur more discussion and help people get started. I have only worked on one application using this design but there are many things I like about it. Of course there are big areas that could use improvement (such as the problem of making reusable serializers). I hope to work more in this area and provide more and better examples as I gain experience and receive feedback. Stay tuned, and be sure to check out the source code on Github.

Cover photo by Boris Bruckhauser

The Triangle Startup Weekends are just one way that North Carolina is engaged in healthcare innovation. Brian Moynihan, head of Triangle chapter of Health 2.0, had a longstanding interest in hosting this event in North Carolina. “This was really a dream come true for me,” he said. “Ever since coming to my first Startup Weekend last year, I had wanted to put on a health-centered event. It was a great chance for people who have an innovative idea to get feedback from physicians, developers, HIPAA experts, business people and more.”

But the Startup Weekend isn’t a North Carolina phenomenon. Powered by Google for Entrepreneurs, more than 1,500 events have been held around the world. Each location has the prerogative to organize around a topic of its choice, with past topics including healthcare, education, and more.

Even as the players and topics vary from event to event, the format for the weekend remains highly collaborative and intense: Friday night participants pitch their ideas and self-select to form teams. On Saturday teams are hard at work talking about their concept with help from coaches and experts as they simultaneously work on business plans, branding, and prototypes. Sunday morning everyone is back together bright and early, talking with strangers, friends, and potential users to validate their concept. Finally after a whirlwind of brainstorming and execution, the teams pitch to a panel of investors and experienced entrepreneurs to compete for the glory of having the best idea.

Bobby Bahram, a judge from the Startup weekend and manager at Excelerate Health Ventures, was inspired by the participants. “Seeing passionate entrepreneurs - most of them strangers prior to Friday - morph into a cohesive team to bring ambitious ideas to life is a testament to the dedication of the weekend warriors and our growing entrepreneurial community,” he said. They are fast-paced, high energy, and inspiring weekends.

A few of the ideas that formed during the weekend included an app to keep diabetes patients accountable for taking their blood sugar readings, various concepts for telemedicine, and a fresh take on intubation devices. The winning team developed natural feminine hygiene products using coconut oil.

As a coach for the weekend, I had the opportunity to sit down with a participant from the weekend, Emily Mangone, a PhD student at UNC’s School of Public Health, FHI360 Fellow, and member of the Connect the Docs Startup Weekend team. Here are some insights from our question and answer session:

Why were you interested in participating in this event?

I’ve wanted to participate more in the business aspect of innovative mhealth products. My own research has been towards developing an app related to reproductive health. I wanted to learn about all the elements to a winning team. As a student I don’t have a lot of free time and I wanted to see what that process looked like in a compact period of time.

How did your team merge health with technology?

Our idea started as combination of health and technology through EMRs to make them compatible across different systems, however we were informed that the government is going to mandate openness across EMR platforms. Our final idea, CareStream, was a tool for the documentation of medical information that can be used to organize information about care from different health systems to get a snapshot of someone’s health history. Our team also illustrates the perfect merge: a few doctors, a physician entrepreneur, an MBA student, myself with a public health background, and a tireless programmer. I learned that I need to have one or two programmers if I want to pitch something in such a high tech field like mHealth. Even just to build a website I’d want that level of support.

How do you think events such as this one can enhance the health technology sector in the Triangle?

I think it creates a lot of energy and buzz around innovative ideas. It’s an incubator for talented people who want to work on new problems with other people who have similar interests but different expertise. We want people to have great ideas in the Triangle so we can bring more technology business right to our front door.

What was your biggest takeaway from the weekend?

Pitching a product you love is ideal, but what I got out of the weekend was learning about the process- from finding an idea, researching, putting together a team, doing market research, and more. I got a really cool understand of the process to bring a product to market in the field that I am interested in. I wanted to do something out of my comfort zone so I worked with a diverse team--it was high tech, mobile, and complex. There was just a great group of people I could learn from. I was grateful for what I got out of the event.

What do you see for the future of healthcare and tech?

I think healthcare is rapidly coming down to individual engagement, whether it is online, from your phone or your own home. Through technology, people can be more involved with their care. I’m hopeful for the future of healthcare and hopeful that technology will reduce costs and improve efficiency.

Interested in future Startup weekends? Follow us on Twitter to hear more about mHealth events and sponsorships.

Cover photo by Dr. Farouk
summary: Smashing Boxes participated in the Triangle Health Startup Weekend in North Carolina. The Triangle Startup Weekends are just one way that North Carolina is engaged in healthcare innovation.
title: Triangle Startup Weekend Engages Innovators to Improve Healthcare

There’s a saying that goes something like “the plumber has the worst plumbing on the block.” Well, we wouldn’t say we have the worst website by any means, but we’ll admit we’ve been busy growing and working with our great clients the past few years without giving as much dedication to our own site. At the end of last year we sat down and made a decision: we needed a new site that would show off what we've been up to. After a lot of back and forth, debating, concepting, designing, and developing we are excited to launch the new smashingboxes.com.

First, we thought about how we could give potential clients and employees a glimpse into Smashing Boxes sans fluff. The key was showing our work, our people, and our ideas instead of just talking about them. So that’s what we did.

Our Culture page focuses on our people and the diverse, fun day-to-day life that we have here. We have an amazing amount of talented people with different personalities who collectively want to innovate technology and disrupt industries.

You can also check out our latest design work and experimentation on Dribbble.

 

...

As a final note, I am very proud of our team and our company. Thanks guys for all the hard work that went into it! Josh, Dante, Ellen, Vimal, Doug, Michael, Kenneth, Jakop, and Andrew.

You may have heard the terms “Growth Specialist” or “Growth Hacker” before but never quite understood what they were. Maybe you thought they were just buzzwords, or you didn’t even realize they played a role in the marketing world. Well, you’re in the right place to find out the mysteries of “growth.” We’ll give you insight into the next generation of user advocates, Growth Engineers, and why Growth Engineering (GE) is important for you and your business.

The History of Growth Hacking

Growth Engineering stems from Growth Hacking. Growth Hacking combines marketing with technology and is a technique used primarily by startups that don’t have money or experience to implement a big marketing campaign. Ryan Holliday of Fast Company said, “Because [startups] didn't have access to the "luxuries" of an ad budget or the burden of proper training, they were able to be creative enough to broaden the definition of marketing to immense advantage.” The term “growth hacker” was first seen in a blog post by Sean Ellis in 2010. He had meant it to be for the scrappy startups who didn’t have the resources for a traditional approach to market their product. He said, “A growth hacker is a person whose true North is growth," meaning every action is done to promote growth.

Enter Growth Engineering

Growth Engineering builds on the core principle of Growth Hacking: growing the user base! Accruing users is the sole purpose of anything with “growth” in front of it. Obviously you can’t increase users without using some more traditional marketing strategies and techniques, like social media, email, and content marketing, but the difference is the end goal and the methods used to achieve that goal. The traditional methods focus on brand awareness and thought leadership, drawing people to the site or app in the first place. Growth Engineering focuses on keeping them there, and turning the casual user into a brand advocate. In the great words of Tron, “I fight for the users” - that’s what we growth engineers do.

But there is more to Growth Engineering than a more grown up name. This brings us to the second great love of growth engineers: data. A large component of Growth Engineering is testing, data mining, and trend analyzing that gives the holistic view of user’s interactions and leads to user retention. Growth engineers want to measure and increase user conversion at every step of the way to truly understand why and which users convert.

Who Benefits from Growth Engineering

Growth services are applicable to businesses with a web or mobile product. For example, a company trying to drive traffic to an ecommerce site and then increase conversions would benefit greatly from Growth services. Their Growth team would be able to test sale funnels, set up heat-maps, analyze retention and referrals, and so on.

Of course, Growth Engineering is not for everyone. For instance, if a product startup is trying to get brand recognition with a guerrilla marketing campaign, as opposed to a digital marketing initiative, Growth Engineering is not for them.

Using Growth Engineering to Compound Your Marketing Efforts

To build upon your current marketing efforts, Growth Engineers can also employ Search Engine Optimization (SEO), Pay Per Click (PPC) ads, and other Search Engine Marketing (SEM) tactics that increase site traffic. The key differentiator between traditional marketing efforts and Growth Engineering is the focus on getting users to stay, convert, and return time after time to use your product. Growth Engineers focus on testable aspects of a site where the data will tell them what is or is not working so they can optimize the user experience.

Where Can I Find Growth Engineering Services?

We are excited to announce that Smashing Boxes is now available to assist companies with Growth Engineering. Our team will work with you to develop and implement data-driven, sustainable user growth techniques. Stay tuned to our blog to learn more about the rollout of this new service and how it can impact your bottom line.

Sometimes the most efficient way to rejuvenate is to take a break from actually working. Google has a practice where engineers spend 20 percent of their time on company-related projects that appeal to their personal interests. They take a break from normal projects and create something that lets their creative pulses beat a little faster. In fact, you’ve probably heard of some of the projects that have come out of the 20% time. They include Gmail (really!), Google News, AdSense, Google Talk and Google Sky.

At Smashing Boxes, we’re all about encouraging our team to hone their talents in a personal way, too. Helen Vasconcelos, iOS Developer

"I'm specifically working on the server back-end of the application and also the iOS side of things," she said.
