body:
As a product owner, you have probably questioned how to use the data that you collect from your web analytics tools to grow your business.

Web analytics give great insights into how users interact with your site or content, but there are limitations to how much the default settings will tell you about your site. If you want to get higher level insights, you will have to go to your web developer and have them code something for you.

This series of articles will give you some ideas on how to make the shift from passively analyzing to actively growing your users. This might be as simple as changing the setup of your analytics account or implementing a few additional tools. Let’s start from the beginning with web analytics.

The majority of people and businesses use Google Analytics as their primary web analytics tool. It is a robust, free tool that has quite a lot to offer. After you have it set up on your site you can start collecting data. The data is compiled in different reports as follows:

  • Audience Reports- Reports that specify who is looking at your site and where they are viewing from
    • Geography
    • Device Type
    • Browser Type
    • New or Returning
  • Behavior Reports - Reports that indicate the frequency of views, how long the viewer stays on the page and what they look for
    • Behavior Flows
    • Site Content
    • Site Speed
  • Acquisitions Reports - Reports that tell the product owner where site visitors are coming from and what actions they take while on the site
    • Channels
    • All Traffic
    • All Referrals
  • Real Time Reports - Reports that allow you to monitor activity as it happens
    • Overview
    • Locations
    • Traffic Sources
    • Content
    • Events
    • Conversions

You can learn a lot from just these settings, but there are more sophisticated options/reports in Google Analytics which will give you greater insights into to your site data. However, these reports will require a more advanced setup to actually gather data you need. For example, if you have an e-commerce site, you will need to collect data that is specific to your purchase funnel. For more complex steps like this you may need to talk to your web developer or an analytics service provider to assist you (we’ll have more on e-commerce later in this series).

Here are some analytics tips that anyone with admin access to your Google Analytics can tackle that will allow you to better understand your users. Start by performing an audit of your setup to make sure it's correctly implemented. All of these can be performed in the admin portal of your account.

1. Check that the tracking code is in the head tag of your website. A simple test to check this is to visit the Real Time tab in Google Analytics Reporting while you are on the site to see if it shows that you are active on the site.

2. Our recommended Google Analytics account structure is to have an All Web Site Data view, a Filtered view, and a Test view. To create a view, navigate to Admin and “Create new view” under View:

Clearly name these views so that their content will be recognizable to anyone looking at your data. For example, “Company Name Filtered View”. Your newly created views will now be visible in the View dropdown:

Note: If you make a new view you won’t see any data that was collected prior to when you created the view. Don't be alarmed. Unfortunately that is how it works if you didn’t create the views when you first installed Google Analytics.

3. Filter out your own IP address. You don’t want your sessions skewing your site data, but make sure you DO NOT add a filter to your All Web Site Data view. This filter should be added to your Filtered view or Test view. To create a filter, navigate to your Filtered view in the View drop down:

Once you select your Filtered view, navigate to Filters and click the “+ New Filter” button:

This opens the “add filter” page where you can name your filter and select the filter parameters:

Filters do not apply to historical data, but from now on you won’t be tracked on your own site and luckily, you still have your untouched All Website Data view. Best practice is to first add the filter to your Test view to check if it is filtering your data as expected. If so, then you can add the filter to your Filtered view.

4. If you have a search bar on your site, make sure you are tracking what people are searching for. This is NOT Keyword tracking, which Google has reduced the usability of with most showing up as (not provided). However if your site has a search bar on it, you can see what terms users are searching for. This gives you insights into what your users are coming to your site for and what they expect to find on your site, which can aid in what you should use in your content to improve SEO.

To set up Site Search Tracking, we recommend navigating to View Settings in your Test view. Scroll down to find “Site Search Settings” and switch “on” site search tracking. In the Query Parameter field, you must enter the word or character that defines the internal search term. For example, smashingboxes.com/?s=pass+google+analytics+exam, the query parameter is the “s”.

Click save and remember that this only turns on site search tracking for the selected view. Once you check that it is working for the Test view, feel free to add it to any view.

These are simple implementations that will give you more accurate user data and information on how users navigate through your site. Growth Engineering focuses on growing and retaining users and these are great configurations to get you started.

Next up, check out this tutorial on button tracking using Google Tag Manager.
summary: As a product owner, it's important to know how to utilize data you collect from your web analytics tools to grow your business and product.
title: Growth Engineering 101: Google Analytics Essentials

body:
What is TDD?

At its core, Test Driven Development (TDD) is a very simple idea: write a test before writing a new feature. Although Kent Beck is often credited with the discovery of TDD, he himself says he found it described in an ancient book about programming on tape. The book described manually typing the expected output on one tape and then programming until the actual output matches the expected output. The principle may have been around earlier but Kent Beck is responsible for popularizing it through his 2002 book, Test-Driven Development: By Example.

This "test-first" concept is in opposition to our natural instinct to start writing code as soon as we come up with an implementation in our head, however naïve it may be. But what some developers don't realize is that by writing code without tests, they are relying on a poor man's TDD. The developer writes a tentative method, then starts a debugger and manually triggers the method with ad hoc data. As soon as it seems to be working, he moves on to other code. Periodically the developer runs the entire application and performs a few sanity checks just to be sure everything works together. Finally, the code is deployed and the inevitable bug reports stream in. Bugs are patched quickly, often uncovering new bugs which are sometimes caught before they go live on production. Assuming the application doesn't require constant addition of new features, the app continues running and the frequency of bug reports gradually lessens until finally an equilibrium is reached in which all bugs are either fixed or are well-enough understood to be considered "quirks" or even "features".

TDD encourages developers to admit that each line of code needs testing. Rather than testing in an ad hoc way, a test framework should be used in order to explicitly define tests. And if we're going to write tests for our code, why not write the test first so that we have something with which to check our work? TDD is the logical conclusion of the premise that tests help us write better code.

Writing a test in the Test Driven Development style is similar to the old practice of typing expected output on tape. If we know our inputs we should have an expectation about what the exact output of our code will be. We can't test every possible value for each input, but we can at least test an expected range of values. Code should be written in such a way as to handle values that are outside of expected ranges. Tests can be either positive, affirming something works, or negative, ensuring that bad data raise exceptions.

Let's look at the simplest example. How can we use TDD to write an addition function?

Set up

First we write an empty test and an empty class in order to get things running.

addition1_spec.rb

require 'rspec/core'
require './addition1'
describe Addition do
  it "adds two numbers" do
  end
end

additional1.rb

class Addition
end

Now run the test:

rspec ./addition1_spec.rb

And we get:

.
Finished in 0.00024 seconds (files took 0.09515 seconds to load)
1 example, 0 failures

This step is to make sure we don't have any problems with our testing environment. We can now proceed to the actual test writing.

Test first

Now we'll add a failing test. This is the "Red" part of the "Red, Green, Refactor" test cycle.

addition2_spec.rb

require 'rspec/core'
require './addition2'
describe Addition do
  it "adds two numbers" do
    result = subject.add(2, 2)
    expect(result).to eq(4)
  end
end

subject is a new instance of Addition. When we call add on subject with the arguments 2, 2 we expect the result to equal 4. eq is Rspec's equivalent to the == operator.

addition2.rb

class Addition
  def add(x, y)
 end
end

We write the empty add method so that our test can run without throwing an exception. The test case will fail because result doesn't equal 4, not because of a NoMethodError.

And run the test:

rspec ./addition2_spec.rb

F
Failures:
  1) Addition adds two numbers
     Failure/Error: expect(result).to eq(4)
       expected: 4
            got: nil
       (compared using ==)
     # ./addition2_spec.rb:8:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
Finished in 0.00074 seconds (files took 0.36751 seconds to load)
1 example, 1 failure
Failed examples:
rspec ./addition2_spec.rb:6 # Addition adds two numbers

As expected, our test fails because we didn't actually implement the Addtion#add method.

Implement the method

Now write just enough code to pass the test.

addition3.rb

class Addition
  def add(x, y)
    x + y
  end
end

And run the test:

rspec ./addition3_spec.rb

.
Finished in 0.00035 seconds (files took 0.06439 seconds to load)
1 example, 0 failures

Our test passes. Now we'd go on to refactoring if this were a more realistic example. For each change we make we re-run our test and ensure that everything is still working as expected.

This is the simplest example of what TDD looks like. In a future blog post we'll look at more realistic examples.

What's the controversy over?

So if TDD can help us write better code, why would some developers oppose it?

Recently a debate began over a keynote and blog post by David Heinemeier Hansson, original author of Ruby on Rails. His main concern with TDD centers around the possibility of design damage due to a dogmatic test-drivenness that insists on keeping tests fast at all costs, extensive mocking, and 100% coverage at the unit level. Kent Beck and Martin Fowler, both proponents of TDD, held a series of conversations with David in which they each described the benefits and shortcomings of TDD and attempted to clear up some misconceptions about the terminology and best practices associated with TDD.

As influential as each of them are, their opinions will continue to influence developers as they face the same trade-offs. The debate will continue at least until we come up with better practices, but many fundamental things will stay the same. All engineering involves trade-offs, so there will never be a silver bullet that solves all problems. We shouldn't neglect the collected wisdom of those who have gone before us. If we do neglect their experiences, we will inevitably repeat their mistakes and make their discoveries vain as we struggle to re-discover on our own.

In future blog posts, I will look more at the evidence that TDD works, look at some practical examples, and explore alternatives to TDD.

Check out TDD for beginners here.
summary: The "test-first" concept is in opposition to our natural instinct to start writing code as soon as we come up with an implementation in our head, however naïve it may be. But what some developers don't realize is that by writing code without tests, they are relying on a poor man's TDD.
title: Test Driven Development (TDD) Part I -- Background

There are many things that I love about using Balsamiq Mockups. For starters, saved mocks are easier to find on my computer instead of scattered throughout my various notebooks. More importantly, I can quickly create a wireframe that looks better than my hand drawings, but translates the roughness of a sketch.

Unfortunately the program does not have an infinite canvas in which to work. The workspace area will only adjust vertically and horizontally as you move your elements around the canvas. I’m coming from an Adobe background where I’m easily able to zoom out or pan around and actually have some space between my design and the edge of the viewport. This may not seem like a big deal, but it really irks me. It irks me real bad.


Luckily, there’s a pretty simple workaround that solves my problem. Just add a small element to the page and drag it far down to the bottom right, farther than you feel you’ll need space for your mockup. The Magical Extra Element allows you to scroll both horizontally and vertically past your mockup, granting a little breathing room between the mockup and the edges of the canvas. Maybe I’m just weird, but this little trick really helped me get into using Balsamiq Mockups more often.

I hope this helps! Do you have any tips you’d like to share? I’m all ears (well, eyes). Comment below with your hacks.

Let’s address the elephant in the room: healthcare websites. What’s the deal? Too often they’re information-heavy and design deprived. Having dedicated my career to both the creative and healthcare industries, I’m well aware of the problem.

In my Master’s of Public Health program I worked with statistical software, tore apart published research, and learned to speak in acronym alphabet soup. However, I didn’t learn what goes into building web and mobile applications, nor the tools necessary for it like Photoshop or UXPin. And this is okay. We are not supposed to know those things. But we should be savvy enough to hire people who do.

As the Digital Health Strategist for a design and web development agency, I’ve seen first hand the impact that user research, experience design, and technical innovation can have for health organizations. The result of integrating these best practices is a website or product that your users will reach for. Here are a few tips for attacking this design challenge:

  • Keep it simple, but significant. Chances are your audience is comprised of patients, the general public, or people with health-related questions. They may not know the inside jargon and 10-syllable words that are the norm in our industry. Talk to your audience simply, remembering that you’ll get your message across best if it is easy to understand.
  • Cut through the noise. There is a global hunger for accessible health information, ranging from finding the right specialist at a hospital, to appointment scheduling, to understanding personal health records. How do you cut through the noise? With well-executed design, relevant content, and paying attention to your audience’s needs. Your design speaks volumes about your credibility and relevance as an organization.
  • Consult with digital design experts. They can provide insight about intuitive navigation and how to organize an information-heavy site or application. Use those conversations to find the right digital partner to bring your website or mobile app to life.
  • Design for people. Address your audience’s needs at each stage of the design and development process and turn the focus toward the “human” in human-centered design. See how we helped Duke, the CDC, and the deBeaumont Foundation do that with Practical Playbook.

So let's use our favorite word - innovate - and change our industry's approach to web and mobile design. User-friendliness coupled with smart, simple design are key to creating a real impact on our target populations. It's time to disrupt the status quo and start making websites and apps people will actually want to use. Check out our latest design work and experimentation on Dribbble.

About the author: Katie Donohue McMillan, MPH is the Digital Health Technology Strategist at Smashing Boxes as well as a founding member of the Triangle mHealth Consortium. During her MPH program at UNC-Chapel Hill she successfully lobbied for a Public Health Entrepreneurship course to introduce students to the world of startups. She has experience working for USAID, Care International and the UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health.
summary: The majority of public health and healthcare digital materials and products are ugly. What can be done about this?
title: Healthcare, Your Website Doesn’t Have to Be Ugly

Chef is like Rails for systems integration. It’s a framework designed to create infrastructure as code.

There are three parts to chef: server, client, and the command line tools. For the server we are going to use Hosted Chef which is free for up to 5 nodes.

First let’s get the client set up.

Client Setup

Install the chef gem:

gem install chef

Now create a .chef/knife.rb file in your project’s root directory:

Notice the environment variables being called there? Yes, we need to set them up.

Setting Up Our Environment

This is a pretty good guide on signing up with Opscode for Hosted Chef and downloading the required .pem files.

So now that you’ve set up your user and organization on Hosted Chef, you need to add them to your environment. .bashrc should be a good place to put this.

Let’s check that everything’s good:

knife node list

That should show you a list of your organization’s nodes.

Import Cookbooks

Cookbooks are collections of recipes. Importing them from Opscode’s community cookbooks repository is as easy as:

knife cookbook site vendor [cookbook-name]

This command will pull down a git repository containing the cookbook and then merge it with masterBe careful if you were working in another branch!

Important Make the cookbooks directory in the root of your app and commit before pulling down any cookbooks. Be sure to do touch cookbooks/.gitkeep before committing to make sure git keeps that directory.

Assuming we are going to set up a Rails server with Unicorn and a HAProxy load balancer, let’s start with the following cookbooks:

knife cookbook site vendor application knife cookbook site vendor apt knife cookbook site vendor git knife cookbook site vendor haproxy knife cookbook site vendor mongodb knife cookbook site vendor users

Now you need to upload the cookbook to your chef server:

knife cookbook upload -a

Now I had some trouble with the mongodb cookbook. There was a syntax error so I forked it and submitted a pull request. The cookbook author accepted the request but the community cookbooks repo was not updated. So I used the knife-github-cookbooks gem to install the latest cookbook from github:

knife cookbook github install edelight/cookbooks

Add Roles

A little terminology:

Node: One server instance

Environment: Chef determines which recipes to run based on which role and environment you’ve chosen. So a role ‘webserver’ can have different recipes for a ‘production’ environment and a ‘staging’ environmentRoleTags representing related functionality

So to create a role we create a roles directory at the root of our project. Then we can add files such as roles/base.rb

Important See the following section on data bags to set up the users and change the your_name value accordingly.

We need to add this to our chef server, just like we added the cookbooks above:

knife role from file roles/base.rb

Notice Roles can also be created with the knife tool, as JSON objects, or through chef server’s management interface.

Data Bags

Before we deploy, we need to have a look at our users cookbook. The documentation states that you need to create a data bag for users:

knife data bag create users

We’ll need a directory to put the user file in (do this in the root of your Rails app):

mkdir -p data_bags/users

Now we can create a user. Open data_bags/users/your_name.json and make it look like this:

{ "groups": "sysadmin", "ssh_keys": "ssh-rsa AAAAB3Nz...", "id": "your_name", "shell": "/bin/bash" }

Important Be sure to change your_name to the user name you actually want to use and paste your user’s public SSH key into the ssh_keys value.

We’ll need another data bag for our application, call it data_bags/rails_demo.json

Upload this data bag with:

knife data bag from file apps data_bags/rails_demo.json

Setting up EC2

Sign into your Amazon AWS web console and create a security group, single_instance_production and open the following ports:

  • 22 – ssh
  • 80 – haproxy load balancer
  • 22002 – haproxy administrative interface
  • 8080 – unicorn Rails application

First install some dependencies:

gem install net-ssh net-ssh-multi fog highline --no-rdoc --no-ri

Now install the knife-ec2 gem in order to provision EC2 instances:

gem install knife-ec2

Bootstrapping Chef with Ruby 1.9.2

Turns out that chef installs ruby 1.8.7 by default. To fix this we need to add a ‘bootstrap’ file that gets run when the server is provisioned.

Create a file, bootstrap/ubuntu10.04-ruby1.9.2.erb with the following:

This script will run as soon as the server is up and compile ruby from source.

Why not use rvm? Opscode doesn’t recommend it. Seems it causes PATH errors. It’s not too bad though, because normally one ruby and gemset is fine for deploying a single-app server. There are solutions if you really want to use rvm

Launch Instance

For this example we are going to have a node named chef-tutorial

This command should launch a server and configure it with Hosted Chef:

knife ec2 server create --node-name ctr --groups single_instance_production --image ami-7000f019 --flavor m1.small --distro ubuntu10.04-ruby1.9.2 --ssh-key ampms -i ~/.ec2/ampms -x ubuntu --run-list 'role[base],role[rails_demo]'

You should see a bunch of commands executing on the server and finally something like this:

You should now be able to ssh in and see that everything is set up right:

ssh -i ~/.ec2/private_key ubuntu@ec2-50-19-193-102.compute-1.amazonaws.com

Troubleshooting

Files for this tutorial are here.

Enjoyed this article? Check out our technical job openings here.

Kent Lovelace has had a pretty awesome life. He was the first African-American to be hired in the Creative Department of The Martin Agency, worked as graphic designer with world-renowned copywriters and Fortune 500 clients, and adopted a daughter with his wife of 20+ years. Now in his mid-50s, he can say he’s an accomplished front-end web developer learning everything he knows about coding in only 12 weeks.

Kent’s story doesn’t stand alone though. The 21 other students who graduated with him on Friday, Aug. 22 from The Iron Yard Powered by Smashing Boxes can also accept the title of Front-End Engineer or Ruby on Rails Developer. In fact, two of them have already accepted full-time jobs, one with with Validic and one with Smashing Boxes. Students presented to potential employers and the press Friday afternoon in a packed house at the Full Frame Theater on the American Tobacco Campus. Afterwards, employers eagerly spoke with students about their futures after graduation.

The experience was closer to polished product pitches to investors than your typical project presentation. “The apps were branded! They went so far past just the coding of the app,” remarked Jessica Mitsch, the Academy’s Campus Director and person responsible for helping students find jobs. Several groups even wore t-shirts touting the logo they designed for their app.

What were the student’s final projects? Check them out below:

Pladel - Pladel is a mobile health application that uses Validic’s API to sync wearable devices and movement apps into one app that lets users input meals, get recipes from Yummly and score healthy behavior based on preset movement, diet and sleep goals.

Personal Journey - Kent Lovelace chronicles his personal triumphs and tragedies in an interactive timeline website. The site concludes with projects that have come out of his

experience at The Iron Yard Academy powered by Smashing Boxes.

Syth Sandbox - Synth Sandbox is a creative environment for programmers to write and share code examples that are written with timbre.js, a javascript library designed for audio synthesis.

GDI Redesign - The Girl Develop It team created a new site for GDI that is dynamic, responsive, and scalable. The site was rebuilt from the ground up, keeping all the original content in place and adding new features such as a database and API to manage chapter information, a map that makes it easy to find a local chapter, an administrative interface for national and chapter leaders, and a streamlined organization of the existing content.

pett.io - pett.io is a pet profile application, designed to be the destination to showcase the unique qualities of users’ pets. The app lets users create photo galleries, share information or reminisce about the pet.

Reciprocity- This app allows users to share recipes, create potlucks with friends, and draw inspiration from the recipes of others to create unique dishes.

Inter-I - The goal of the project was to create a data set of ideas and the relationships between them. Founder Josh Tarkington exported 40 gigabytes of Wikipedia data and created a way to search an idea and pull up topics that relate. Eventually, the site will help people find things based on context, not keywords.

iSuccess - The purpose of iSuccess is to provide an organized interface for individuals to track their tasks and goals. The use of a intuitive UI design makes it easy for people who have trouble sticking to their plans to actually fulfill their goals. The app was deployed as both a web application and a mobile iOS application.

Festivit - This app helps event and festival organizers manage details and tasks like mobile check-in for attendees. It will be tested at Chatham County's Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival in October.

Pollish - Pollish came out of a Week 4 homework assignment to develop an application that allows users to create and answer multiple choice questions or “polls” and vote. Each question was required to have its own URL.

What do you think of when you hear the words: New York City? What about Detroit? Paris? Cities carry with them feelings about people and businesses, visions of landmarks, or a subtle taste of a certain kind of food. There’s even a legitimate communications theory based on this idea. The Framing Theory suggests that people have certain perceptions about places based on what they’ve heard or seen from media, not from actual experience. Enveloping all of these perceptions and emotions is a city’s brand. And for anyone who lives outside of that city, the brand can have a significant impact on the way they feel about it, whether they would visit, do business, or even move there.

But branding goes deeper than an image. With the world as globalized and networked as it is, every city has to compete for tourists, investment, capital, business, attention, and even respect. How cities communicate their soul and success is crucial for deciding which ones succeed and which ones fail in the rivalry for economic prosperity. In this sense, cities are like companies. Those with a strong and powerful brand have an easier time selling their products and services that are attractive to people and investors. As the city of Raleigh expands and looks to enhance its domestic image, the idea of branding plays a key role in its reputation and perception.

With the recent “Downtown Experience Plan” put into action to reinvent certain parts of downtown Raleigh, I wanted to revisit some prior work done by our own designer, Raleigh Felton, for the exact purpose of rebranding and drawing attraction to a city. Earlier this year, creative agency Baldwin& masterminded the Rebrand Raleigh Instagram account in an effort to create a fresh brand for the City of Oaks. The account is owned by each designer for two weeks, in which they rediscover what Raleigh means to them through the medium of art and illustration. After two weeks, the account is passed to the next audacious designer. Rinse and repeat.

This is the story of Felton’s journey in designing a brand for the city of Raleigh and what it means for all cities seeking out a brand strong enough to carry them into the future:

Inspiration and Discovery

The juxtaposition of old and new leaves a striking impression on those visiting Raleigh for the first time. There’s no doubt it is still a city in transition. Aged, brick buildings along the main street sit in the shadows of glass towers. A rustic-chic coffee shop serving brunch to a fashionable crowd looks out to a grimy, dark bus station. There is both a blending of cultures and eras; and a separation.

Felton began by exploring this separation through design, melding the old and historic with the new and energetic. A city’s brand must be a reflection of the energy, diversity, and individualism of people that give a city it’s unique vibe. The individuality of each person is what makes a city like Raleigh so great. 

Gaining Perspective

Inspiration comes from observing a subject from various angles and perspectives. The art and the textures of cities are startling when you begin to see out the details. In Raleigh, Felton discovered a blending and balance of dissimilar surfaces, textures, and the interlacing of old and new.

Design Elements

Color, patterns, angles, shapes: Each must be carefully selected to reflect the movement and emotion of a city. Together they craft that elusive ‘contemporary symbol’. Is there a pattern that can speak a city in its entirety? Different angles, shapes, and colors represent the individuality of people, businesses, cultures, ideas, and areas. In Raleigh, they all come together to make the city we love.

Real-world Application

Inevitably, these metaphors and impressions must translate to a brand that will function in real life. Great designers know that everything should be crafted with purpose. A logo can have beautiful form and extract feeling from its viewer, yet it still has to fit into context and serve its underlying purpose. Here, Felton applies his designs to various city commodities and institutions. 

What Brands Mean for Cities

A strong brand encompass the meaning of an idea or purpose of an institution, and expresses it to all that view its simple, solitary image. By nature, logos and designs are an evolution. As the institution or idea they represent changes over time, so must they. And as the city of Raleigh continues to shift and grow with each new face, business, and idea, so will the logos, designs, and words that attempt to capture it. The same can be applied to every city. The brand of a place reflects the soul of its inhabitants.

View more of Raleigh Felton’s branding and design work here.
summary: As the city of Raleigh expands and looks to enhance its domestic image, the idea of branding plays a key role in its reputation and perception. This is the story of Felton’s journey in designing a brand for the city of Raleigh and what it means for all cities seeking out a brand strong enough to carry them into the future.
title: What Cities Stand to Gain from a Strong Brand

The Chrome App Launcher is Windows-only at the moment, but Mac and Linux users can expect the update sometime in the near future.

Earlier this month Google released an update to it’s Chrome Web browser that enabled a new app launcher on the desktop. Available only on Windows and Chrome OS for the time being, the Chrome App launcher marks another step along Google’s path to convergence for its software platform, but more than that it marks a shift in the way we think about applications.

Chrome Apps (still just called Chrome Apps for now) are security-sandboxed applications built with HTML, CSS and Javascript that have access to some system hardware, such as the GPU and connected devices, as well as the Chrome APIs already used by their Web counterparts. Gaining access to the desktop means Chrome Apps can perform offline functionality without having to rely on Local Storage and the size limitations that come with it, or on the more fully-featured but significantly more complex Application Cache. Utilizing the same technologies used to build Web apps today means Web developers just gained a new platform they can deploy to.

The average end user doesn’t care what their app is built with as long as it loads quickly and does what it’s told. Web technologies have been mature enough to create attractive, responsive interfaces for some time now, but a browser is still needed in most cases to render the code. Chrome Apps have none of the standard Chrome browser controls, so visually they can look like anything. Even native desktop apps are typically governed to some extend by the design of the parent OS.

The challenge and opportunity exists in taking advantage of this paradigm shift in app definition. The Web can’t do everything, but it’s well on it’s way. Data-centric apps are prime targets and well-suited to the Chrome platform. Every successful app that runs in the browser — think Mint, Soundcloud, Facebook, Hulu, not to mention Google Apps as a whole — are all prime examples of what is possible with the browser. Without an address bar and a back button all of these apps would be indistinguishable from something out of the Mac App Store.

Applications like Adobe Photoshop, FinalCut Pro, and Maya are a ways away from becoming Chrome Apps. Resource heavy, media-centric applications benefit from performance gains of native code and direct access to hardware — two things most browser apps can’t make use of… yet. As more of the barriers between Web and desktop are broken down and Web apps get better access to hardware, Web counterparts to these high-powered media apps will likely be more commonplace.

Chrome Apps have always felt kind of like glorified browser extensions, even with a shiny marketplace and the ability to sync when you sign into Chrome. There are definitely good Chrome Apps available, but even some of those are just the app website wrapped in a container.

Moving to make them “first-class citizens” — something that will sound familiar to those following the development of Ubuntu Phone — is an important step in moving the Web forward as an application platform. Even Windows now has provisions for developing with HTML and Javascript, to say nothing of more web-centric operating systems like Firefox OS and Amazon’s Fire platform. It’s clear from current trends that the days of installing to the desktop are nearly at an end.

Whether Chrome Apps usher in this new era of hardware-accessing, HTML-based applications single-handedly remains to be seen, but anyone creating desktop-only software without an eye on the Web is poised to be left behind by their users.

Smashing Boxes is a web and mobile app development company know for creating a lasting experience through bold design and disrupting the status quo. We are entrepreneurs and craftsmen first, and a digital creative agency second. Inspired by our visionary clients, we transform ideas into innovative web and mobile applications. Take a look at our work.

Every marketer knows that to create useful and interesting content is to know your audience. It’s no different with website owners. The number of tools that exist to analyze and track your readers is endless, but most times they force you to go from dashboard to dashboard to manually connect the dots. We’ve already discussed Google Analytics, but what you may not know is how powerful GA Event Tracking and Tag Manager can be.

Tracking user interactions is so important to optimizing your site, and event tracking is a digital analyst’s best friend. Events act as bread crumbs to your business goals. There are two categories that events fall into: Micro Conversions and Macro Conversions.

Some examples of Micro and Macro conversions:

Micro Conversions Macro Conversions
Contact form pageview          E-commerce sale completion
Newsletter sign up Contact form submission
Downloading a PDF Membership sign up

Though events give amazing insights about your site and whether users are on your path to a goal completion, it requires a developer to make it work. Events have the following components which map directly to elements in the Analytics Reports interface:Micro conversions often lead interest in your company or product, so you shouldn’t only focus on Macro conversions. But if you aren’t tracking Micro conversions, you could miss out on some great data and may not be be able to fully understand your goal paths.

  • Category (required): The name you supply for the group of objects you want to track
  • Action (required): Paired with a category, used to define the user interaction taken
  • Label (required): Gives more detail to the action
  • Value: (optional): Associates a value with the event (ex. monetary)
  • Non-Interaction (optional): Indicates that the event hit will not be used in bounce rate

A developer will have to connect the event with the asset that you would like to track:

<a href="#" id=“Product1” onClick=" ga(‘send', ‘event’, 'category’, ’action’, ‘label’, value);">Download</a>

Here’s a simple example. Let’s say that you would like to track how many times a product PDF is downloaded through a button click. We would have to write a similar line of code to the one above that will give us the information we want in our GA account:

  • Category (required): PDF_Downloads
  • Action (required): Click_Download
  • Label (required): Product1_PDF
  • Value: (optional):

<a href="#" id=“Product1” onClick=" ga(‘send', ‘event’, 'PDF_Downloads’, ’Click_Download’, ‘Product1_PDF’);">Download</a>

Now we will be able to see this data and we can answer questions like, “how many times are our PDFs downloaded?” or “Why do we need to spend time creating downloads?”

Even though event tracking is great, you may be realizing that this is not the quickest way to implement event tracking on your site. It can also be tedious and time-consuming for a developer to have to place pieces of code throughout the site, especially if you have multiple PDFs all with different titles.

Google also recognized this pain point and created a great tool called Google Tag Manager (GTM) that allows you to quickly and easily implement events for your site. Tag Manager acts as a bridge for site owners to tag important events on their site without help from a developer. 

The way GTM has made life easier is that you only have to load a code snippet once. This snippet is called the container. The container needs to be placed in immediately after the opening <body> tag.

Ex. of a GTM container:

<!-- Google Tag Manager --> <noscript><iframe src="//www.googletagmanager.com/ns.html?id=GTM-XXXXXX" height="0" width="0" style="display:none;visibility:hidden"></iframe></noscript> <script>(function(w,d,s,l,i){w[l]=w[l]||[];w[l].push({'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(),event:'gtm.js'});var f=d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0], j=d.createElement(s),dl=l!='dataLayer'?'&l='+l:'';j.async=true;j.src= '//www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id='+i+dl;f.parentNode.insertBefore(j,f); })(window,document,'script','dataLayer','GTM-XXXXXX');</script> <!-- End Google Tag Manager -->

Once the container is loaded on your site you will never have to hardcode for an event again! Setting up an event in GTM is similar to the “old way” of event tracking. You still need to identify a category, action, label, value, and non-interaction. You can see in the image below that the same identifiers are used as the example before, but there is something different in the label text box.

What is in the text box is called a macro. This macro will return the id attribute of the element that was clicked. Going back to the example above it will return “Product1”. This makes tagging easier because this one tag will work for every PDF on your site that has an id; just make sure your developer gives each a clear and unique id. You do not have to create a tag for individual PDFs on your site.

You can learn even more about your website and its users by becoming versed in Google Analytics and taking the  GAIQ Exam.

*With Ross Ozburn
summary: Website owners can get to know their website better by utilizing event tracking and Google Tag Manager.
title: Google Tag Manager and Event Tracking

An interview series with Mark Braunstein, Director of the Health Systems Institute at Georgia Tech, and columnist at InformationWeek.

A decade or so ago only a very few professionals used the term logistics, yet it very quickly moved from an IT and Operations handle into the boardroom — and eventually to consumers when it became the tagline and promotional vanguard for UPS. Much like what manufacturing and retail experienced when data flow was systematized for operational efficiency, the health care industry is now experiencing: the development, propagation and consumerization of a data logistics system.

Dr. Mark Braunstein, a physician who also heads up the Health Systems Institute at Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech) in Atlanta, works with nearly every aspect of the medical industry to help develop a sensible and efficient approach to information management in medical industries. We interviewed the good doctor to help educate us about what’s current in the world of Healthcare IT. What we learned was so thought provoking that we thought we’d share it here. Over the next few weeks, we will submit for you a series of blogs about this bourgeoning industry in hopes that you, too, find the information inspiring.

The Factors Impacting Health Informatics

Call it what you will – Electronic Health Records, Healthcare IT, Digital Health – digitizing patient records, caregiver operations and pharma/device manufacturer information is having enormous impact on consumers, healthcare providers, payers and even entrepreneurs.  Health information for every American will soon be stored in the cloud, for access by any physician to whom the patient’s permission is given. And that data is further expanding the processes being developed not only for payer/provider, but for the pharmaceutical and biotech industries at large. Our conversations with Dr. Braunstein highlighted three major factors driving and impacting the world of healthcare informatics: Big Data; Finance/the Affordable Care Act; Entrepreneurship.

We will explore these topics in future blog posts. But first, we asked Dr. Braunstein for an overview of the environment in which health care is operating. He shared the following insights into the State of Healthcare:

  • Chronic diseases impact care and cost: between 70% and 95% of health care costs are directly related to treating chronic diseases. Many of these are on the rise, such as diabetes, heart conditions and cancer among them. In fact, a surprising number of people battling chronic diseases are battling multiple chronic diseases.
  • Too few primary care physicians: In the United States, only 12% of doctors are primary care physicians. This seems almost absurd to those in foreign countries. Compare it to France, for example, where the vast majority of doctors are primary care, healthcare costs are half of that of the US, and life expectancy is significantly longer as well.
    • Americans see a complicated network of specialists for treatment… quite often, up to 14 different doctors each year. Patient data must be shared among each of these care givers in order for appropriate diagnosis and treatments to be given.
  • Doctors are moving to EMR, but slowly: Only about 50% of private physicians have made the move to fully compliant electronic medical records, and approximately 75% of hospitals are ‘there.’ But they’re beginning to move more quickly now as they will very soon be left out of the network entirely if they are not in compliance.

These factors, along with those we will address in future blog posts, actually spell out significant opportunity for creative businesses. If you have an interest in finance, data access/storage and security, or entrepreneurship, read part 2 of the series The Impact of Healthcare IT Part 2: Big Data, Big Cloud, Big Finance.

Julia Elman isn't your typical front-end programmer. On top of being a designer by trade and instructor at the Iron Yard Academy powered by Smashing Boxes, she's a self-taught programmer, career go-getter and now an author. We sat down with Julia to discuss her new book, Lightweight Django, and how she got to where she is today. Listen to the podcast interview in its entirety below.



Can you tell us a little about how you came down this career path?

I’d like to think it was curiosity mostly…when I started over a decade ago the web was just sort of emerging, I’ve always been somebody who like problem solving as well. I think being a designer and loving problem solving is just part of your job. As a developer it’s the same thing.

You had a partner on this book, Mark Lavin. Tell me a little bit about how that came about.

Mark and I actually worked at Caktus Consulting Group for a few years and we just really enjoy working together and work well together. So we decided to write a book.

Why specifically Django?

I’ve been doing Django since about 2008…I fell in love with the framework and Python and the whole community in general. It’s a great community to be involved with. It’s something I’ve been doing for awhile now and this book is really about de-mystifying Django. It’s just a lot of fun to be able to do that.

Right now your book is on early release, “raw and unedited,”  what exactly does that mean, what’s the thought behind that and when can we expect the final product?

The early release is really meant to get a backing…it’s really just to create some buzz and get people excited about this awesome new thing that is going to be part of the Django community and Python community and also Javascript as well. The book really brings in this sort of client side, back end infrastructure, how those two meet, how they work together.

So tell us a little bit about what audience this book is designed for and what you hope they take away from it?

The audience is really for people who don’t have a lot of experience bringing in client-side and back-end work into a Django environment. It’s definitely not a beginner book.

So you started off as a designer and programmer, you still are, what was the biggest challenge in transforming form that to author?

A decision. I’m a person who likes challenges and I don’t understand the concept of boredom so really it was like what’s the next challenge for me and my career?

What kind of advice would you give to other programmers who might follow down the same path of authorship?

Find something that you love. Maybe something that you want to learn a little more about…Also find a really good editor.

So after completion of the e-book, is this book going to be available in print?

Yes, it will be available later on this year.

You are a clear example of a woman who’s been very successful in tech. What kind of advice would you have for other women who want to follow down the path of programming?

Don’t give up. Don’t quit, if it’s something you love. Don’t let things stand in your way. The hard part is going at it alone…get that support group.

Since the advent of the smartphone, the mobile health (mHealth) market has been growing steadily into a billion dollar industry and is projected to be $26B by 2017. This means that although there are currently around 17,000 mobile health apps on the market, the door of opportunity for new apps is still wide open to create new solutions for improving health and wellness. So, once you come up with an mHealth app idea, how do you differentiate your app and ensure that health care professionals and/or consumers will actually use yours when the landscape is so crowded?

Does your app solve a legitimate health problem?

The most important driver for an mHealth app should be that it solves a valid pain point in healthcare. There are many areas of health that still need solutions and mHealth has the potential to solve many existing and emerging issues help people save on healthcare expenditures.

Is your app easy to use?

Doctors and consumers are busy with their jobs and everyday lives, so they are unlikely to use anything that requires too much extra effort. When designing an app, you want to maximize the value it provides for everyone who is using it, whether the app is saving time for doctors who are interacting with patients through a messaging platform or facilitating access to health information for patients on the go.

Does a solution already exist? If so, what makes your solution better?

The mHealth market is competitive, so it is important to do research ahead of time to ensure that your time isn’t being wasted developing something that is already on the market and has a large following. Differentiate yourself by talking to health care professionals and consumers before and while building your app so that you know you are building something that serves a purpose.

Does your app empower patients?

Patient empowerment is key to changing and improving long-term patient behavior, especially for medication adherence and other preventative health measures. If your app enables people to take control of their health outcomes and facilitates healthy behavior, healthcare professionals are more likely to see the benefits of the app and prescribe it to their patients.

Will your app require FDA approval?

Recently, the FDA published guidelines outlining the types of apps that they will be regulating. When developing your app, ensure that you know if your app will be considered a medical device or medical device accessory and will be regulated by the FDA. Take a look at our post detailing the recent FDA regulations around mHealth applications and if your app will be impacted.

Now that you know what aspects make an mHealth app effective, think about what areas of health where mHealth apps would improve health outcomes. One of the areas where mHealth could make a big impact is medication non-adherence. To read more about this problem and how mHealth can help, download our white paper.

So you got the new iOS 7, huh? Believe it or not, under all that new flat prettyness lies a ton of neat new APIs and frameworks! I am going to briefly go into a new tool for iOS developers called UIKit Dynamics.

UIKit Dynamics is a full physics engine integrated into UIKit. Using UIKit Dynamics allows developers to create user interfaces that feel real. This means that UI objects can be considered physical objects that respond to gestures, touches, and changes to orientation. Developers may add behaviors such as gravity, attachments, and forces.

Want to see this in action? Go ahead and pull out your iPhone (sorry Android users!). On the lock screen there is a camera icon in the bottom right to allow you to quickly navigate to your camera app. Tap and hold on the icon and drag the screen almost half way up – now let go and watch what happens. Did you see the bounce effect at the bottom of the screen? Try again, but this time only drag the view up so you can just see the take picture button. You will notice there was even less bounce. Now the fun part. Do the same thing, but instead of just letting it go, swipe your finger toward the bottom of the screen like you’re throwing the view down. You will noticeably see a larger bounce from the view depending how fast you swiped the view and if you swipe it fast enough, it will bounce all the way up and launch the camera app!

In this example I will add a 100×100 square (green) at the top of my view. I will then add a barrier bar (yellow) about half way down the view. The square will drop from the top (gravity) and bounce off the bar (collision) and then bounce to the bottom of the view.

That is all, I hope you enjoyed learning something new that iOS 7 has to offer! I am looking forward to utilizing UIKit Dynamics into a real world application to give it that extra special touch. The Iron Yard powered by Smashing Boxes is eager to begin the first semester of classes on June 2nd at Durham’s American Tobacco Campus (and is still accepting applications for the front-end course!) It’s been a busy time of growth, learning, and lots of fun planning all of the amazing things students will encounter in their time at The Academy.

The Academy is a code school that offers 12-week, intensive courses that incorporate hands-on learning experience with teaching, mentorship, collaboration, and real world skills building. The program is very fast paced and students work on assignments that build knowledge cumulatively. In the end, students graduate from the program with a portfolio of their work and are ready to seek employment as junior-level programmers. The Academy comes with an employment guarantee; get a programming job or your money back. Classes will be held in the American Underground, in the heart of the Triangle area’s burgeoning tech scene.

To make things a bit more personal we’d like to introduce you to the Academy‘s profoundly intelligent and inspiring instructors, Clinton and Julia, and wonder-woman Campus Director, Jessica Mitsch.

Clinton Dreisbach

Hi! I’m  Clinton Dreisbach and I am excited to be an instructor with The Iron Yard powered by Smashing Boxes in Durham. I’ve been a programmer since I was 10 and got my hands on an IBM PCJr, and I’ve been writing software professionally for over 15 years, working in everything from Perl to Java to Ruby to Clojure. Of all the languages I’ve used, Ruby has consistently been one of my favorites, so I’m thrilled to be teaching our inaugural Ruby on Rails class in Durham.

I have always loved teaching people and have done plenty of one-on-one mentoring and conference speaking. For the past two years, I’ve been teaching outside of work in programs such as  Citizen Schools and ClojureBridge. I’m looking forward to bringing the skills I’ve learned to The Academy.

When I am not at a keyboard, I am busy being a dad to an amazing toddler and partner to an amazing spouse. In the sliver of time left after all that, I play and design tabletop games and bang out tunes on my ukulele.

Julia Elman

Hello! My name is Julia Elman and I am a designer, developer, and tech education advocate based in North Carolina. I’ve been working my brand of web skills since 2002 and honing my skill set as a front end developer. My creative nature drove me to find work at Hallmark Cards, Inc. in Kansas City in 2007 where I worked on projects such as the Product (RED) campaign andHallmark’s site re-design. From there, I took a dive into Django as a Junior Designer/Developer at World Online in Lawrence, KS. Currently, I am working on a book for O’Reilly Media on called “Light weight Django” which focuses on advanced and light weight techniques when using Django with Javascript (TBR 2014).

In my spare time, I am one of the local Chapter Leaders for  Girl Develop It RDU, a non-profit organization focused on empowering women to learn software programming. In early 2013, I helped teach the initial HTML/CSS class and have since helped grow the chapter to over 600 members, four instructors and multiple teaching assistants. Also in 2013, I helped organize and teach the Teen Tech Camp, a one day for teaching kids 12-18 how to program with Python on a Raspberry Pi.

Joining The Iron Yard powered by Smashing Boxes in Durham is something I am thrilled to have the opportunity to do and I am excited to show the world the talent the Triangle area has to offer!

Jessica Mitsch 

Hello, my name is  Jessica Mitsch and I’m thrilled to be joining The Iron Yard powered by Smashing Boxes as Campus Director!

I unexpectedly stumbled into a career in tech at Red Hat, Inc. after graduating from the College of Charleston with a Religious Studies degree (yes, I was one of those liberal arts majors who thought I’d graduate and venture off to find a solution to world peace.) I wore several hats (pun intended) as a member of the People Team at Red Hat and my experience there led me to love the innovative and ever changing world of technology while gaining an understanding of the the extraordinary gap and need for tech talent.

I have always been passionate about education and believe education must be reformed to meet the challenges of the 21st century. When the incredibly talented folks at The Iron Yard approached me about joining their team to launch a code school in Durham, it just made sense to me.

In my spare time I can be found moving in a studio somewhere – I enjoy dance, yoga and fitness classes. I love to travel, just about anywhere I can go and consider myself somewhat of a health nut.

The school represents a unique partnership between The Iron Yard and Smashing Boxes, marrying credibility and experience with a strong understanding of the local technology landscape. Simply put, both companies are dedicated to the lifelong pursuit of knowledge, helping the Triangle thrive through grassroots initiatives, and giving people, especially women and other underrepresented groups, the chance to find professional success in the technology space.

Smashing Boxes contributes through guest lectures, office hours for students to take advantage of developer knowledge, immersion into our culture and real client work, and various other professional opportunities.

Application designs typically require users to take at least one action after choosing at least one option. Behind each option is at least one rule determining what happens once an action is triggered. Interaction rules are the most fundamental part of an interaction design, affecting everything from the level of user control, to timing and event order, feedback, what happens at the end of an interaction, and more (check out Dan Saffer’s Microinteractions book, for more on rules and interaction structure). There are many factors affecting the usage speed of an application, we will primarily be examining interaction rules in an attempt to demonstrate how their effective design can help make applications easier and faster to use. In short, elimination of options, and their corresponding rules, leads to faster usage speed. Once the design has reached the maximum level of simplicity, there are still many ways to increase usage speed, including creative design based on user research, and elimination of usage error potential.

Application rule sets can be simple or quite extensive. As an example, let’s look at some possible rules for a photo sharing application. The rule set for such an application might contain the following:

  1. If the user is on a photo album page and “Edit album” is selected, display an editable album title field and a list of photographs.
  2. If at least one photo is selected, display “Delete selected” and “Move selected” buttons.

In the above example, the “Delete selected” and “Move selected” buttons appear only when at least one image has been selected. Irrelevant options remain hidden until the user makes them relevant. It’s in this manner that effective rule design can increase usability by limiting user options. Generally speaking, the fewer the options, the fewer the rules, and the faster the usage speed.

The challenge of rule design is knowing your user group well enough to hide or eliminate certain options in a way that feels useful and non-restrictive. Hiding options and revealing them when the time is right, through progressive disclosure, is generally more effective than removing options and content (Check out Jacob Nielsen’s book, Mobile Usability, p. 60 for more on progressive disclosure). This technique can be quite effective if proper trigger affordances are built in to the design so users know how to find hidden content.

Although simplification through elimination of options does wonders for speed of use, there is a point at which further simplification would negatively impact usability.  At this point, the challenge becomes knowing how to work with the necessary complexities.  Larry Tesler, inventor of the cut-and-paste interaction, constructed a law to address the limitations of simplification. According to Tesler’s Law, all activities have inherent complexity, so there is a point at which simplification is no longer an option (Saffer, Microinteractions, p. 67). Accepting such limitations can be challenging, but there is often still ample room for creativity within such constraints.

If user research and testing has been conducted, there are probably many ways to further a design, even under tight constraints and with only basic knowledge of user requirements. As a simple example, let’s look at designing a time picker for an event planning company. With just a small amount of user information, like the fact that users will only create events on or thirty minutes past the hour, we can already begin making more effective decisions. Out of the box most time pickers provide a drop-down list of all hours, and a separate drop-down menu list of all minutes to choose from. If we provide two long lists fill with mostly useless options, the time selection interaction will surely come up short. With basic knowledge of event times, long hour and minutes lists can be combined into one simple list of times in 30-minute increments. A meeting will never be scheduled for 10:03pm, so there is no need to include 10:03 as a selection choice.

After user research, one way to potentially improve interactions is through error prevention. If users of an application easily make mistakes, the design has great potential for improvement through error prevention design. The goal with many designs is to make it impossible for users to do something wrong. However, it is possible to achieve zero or low usage error potential with varying degrees of success. There are different ways to reduce or eliminate usage error potential, but the best approaches take usage flow into consideration. If an application has hundreds of pop-ups, users may never be able to make a mistake, but it will probably feel like hundreds of mistakes have been made-especially if audio feedback accompanies those popups. It may work to eliminate popups, but it will most likely not work to eliminate confirmation questions. One way to mitigate the disruption that a pop-up can create, while maintaining sound error prevention through confirmation checks is with interactive tooltips. A tooltip is subtle enough, when tastefully designed, that it will not overtly interrupt the experience. Since users are focusing directly where the tooltip appears, discoverability is also very high. The combination of high discoverability and marginal disruption of the experience makes tooltips ideal for many error prevention designs. Let’s look at applying tooltip error prevention to a photo sharing application. If one decides to edit a photo album within such an application, making sure to confirm user intent to delete photos is important. Instead of using pop-ups to display confirmation messages, let’s use an interactive tooltip on the delete button.

In the example above, error confirmation messaging has been incorporated in an unobtrusive way. There is less time and effort required to confirm intent.

In some cases, especially with touch screen devices, we could make creative use of gestures for error prevention. Instead of confirming intent with a pop-up, or tooltip, we could require users to make a long swipe gesture in a highlighted area. This swipe trigger could be used in place of a tap trigger, which is final once a user interacts with it. With a swipe, users can decide to stop even after they have started swiping. Also, requiring prolonged intentional focus on the trigger activation lowers the chances of doing something by accident. A great example of this is found in the iOS7 lock and power off screens. An evolved form of skeuomorphism is used effectively in iOS7 interaction design to make things more intuitive and faster to use. The power off screen has a ‘slide to power off’ area at the top and a cancel button all the way at the bottom as far away from the top as possible. A swipe is required to trigger a device shutdown, while simply canceling out of the shutdown screen only requires a tap. In order to even reach the shutdown screen a user must first press and hold the power button. Additionally, through the physical mechanics of the button, users receive both haptic and audio feedback as it is pressed. The subtleties of such interactions, allows for a seamless and fast experience.

After looking at the examples above, we can begin to see there is great potential to improve usage speed through simplification of interactions, user research, and more. Comment below if you have any suggestions or remarks about how usage speed can be improved!

Each Christmas Eve, Santa Claus straps on his boots, harnesses his reindeer, and kisses Mrs. Claus goodbye before racing West across the globe to deliver presents to millions of children. The scientific community understands this feat to be the product of magic. Yet, Santa’s magic isn't foolproof, and it only works when kids believe in the spirit of Christmas. Santa’s previous Sleigh System was built in the 90's and was in need of serious upgrades. So when Santa approached us with the opportunity to build a new User Interface for his sleigh, we were delighted to help out.

Time was of the essence! So, we assembled a top notch team of UI designers and Android developers and invited Santa to visit our office. 

After some collaborative sketch sessions and usability testing, we set to work creating an interface that would provide Santa with critical performance stats and hands-free navigation.

We employed some technological magic of our own. Our solution automatically selects Santa’s best flight path based on weather conditions, commercial flight paths, and bird migration patterns. At a glance, Santa can view upcoming deliveries, time remaining until sunrise, and if a child has been naughty or nice. Santa and his reindeer’s safety is of utmost importance so we built in functionality that allows him to see energy reserves of his reindeer, turn on Rudolf’s nose in poor conditions, and enjoy hands free communication with Mrs. Claus and the elves. To create the UI, our designers used icons created by Iconsmind, Paul Stevens, and Matt Brooks. Want to take a closer look? You can download the source file on Dribbble.  

Of course, after all the hard work was done, there was still time for some fun!

If you've been good this year, our robust and powerful app will seamlessly guide Santa to your house. If you've been bad, well…that’s on you.

Working with an unfamiliar tool-set usually poses some distinct challenges. Invaluable learning takes place when you have to use that tool-set to solve a complex problem. For me, the unfamiliar tool-set was ExpressionEngine and the complex problem was how best to use EE to build the NCSU College of Design website.

Coming from a largely WordPress background I was initially taken aback by some of the paradigms at the core of EE. In WordPress you have posts and custom post types, Drupal has the all powerful node and ExpressionEngine has…channels. The structure of an entry is dictated by the channel it is published in and the fields that channel has. EE’s content storage system is fairly straightforward when implementing a simple brochure site or blog where post types are few and their structure is simple.

The College of Design site however, functions as an informational portal for the department within the larger University. On top of hundreds of informational pages across multiple sections there are staff profiles, galleries of work, dynamically generated content sliders, dynamic backgrounds — and that’s just on the homepage. Well-defined content structure is important in any project and was absolutely vital in this one.

The Problem with Pages

As mentioned above, most of ExpressionEngine’s content management happens via channels. There is the concept of a Page in the vanilla EE install but it’s disabled by default and encapsulated in a separate module. The College of Design site called for hierarchical page relationships with different templates for parent and child pages. It’s a a relatively common mode of organization but proved difficult to implement with channels alone. Therefore, I was faced with an unsavory choice: build and configure the channels so all entries are easily accessible from the same template, or build a template with conditional logic for every sub-category and content type.

The first option makes the front-end code much simpler but results in all the hierarchical content being chucked into the same “bucket” within the CMS, making actual content management a nightmare. The second option makes for templates bloated with conditional statements and hard-coded constants that are then duplicated for each section within the hierarchy. Both would solve the problem but the concessions involved in each were more than I was willing to stomach.

Deus Ex Taxonomy

After the channel-based publishing, the hardest thing for me to wrap my head around was the plugin ecosystem. To its credit, EE is very flexible once you understand how to use it. However, like most content management systems, not all the functionality you want exists out-of-the-box. There is the possibility of extension via modules and plugins but since ExpressionEngine is proprietary software, so too are many of the plugins. Perhaps this is reasonable, but it’s a hard pill to swallow for someone accustomed to building with open source tools. If the WordPress Plugin Directory is a Chinese buffet, then EE charges you $5 for water.

Still, despite much grumbling and dragging of feet, I eventually found my magic bullet in the form of Taxonomy. With it I was able to build hierarchical menus entirely independent of the underlying channel structure and provide override links to any URL on a per-item basis. Entries could now be organized in as many channels as necessary while appearing as one logical section to the user. At the code level I only needed to add a few template tags rather than building a self-generating menu system from the ground up.

Below is the code for a custom menu on one of the departmental landing pages:

As you can see, there are lots of conditionals. Additionally, there’s plenty of fiddling around with URL slugs and entry IDs to get the URL structure to appear right on “sub” pages. It works for this purpose but it’s too specific to use elsewhere.

Enter Taxonomy:

It’s much more concise to say the least. Taxonomy does all the footwork of building out sub-navs, adding active classes and handling URLs. Granted, there is still some configuration overhead and there are several options and functions that I didn’t use for this build. Even so, dropping Taxonomy in was akin to sweeping that CRT monitor onto the floor and replacing it with one of those new hypercrystal OLED widescreen cinema displays. You know, the ones with the iPod dock.

Cover photo by Martin Fisch
summary: Working with an unfamiliar tool-set usually poses some distinct challenges. Invaluable learning takes place when you have to use that tool-set to solve a complex problem. For me, the unfamiliar tool-set was ExpressionEngine and the complex problem was how best to use EE to build the NCSU College of Design website.
title: Hierarchical Navigation with ExpressionEngine and Taxonomy

body:
The anticipation in advance of the Apple event this week was similar to that prior to the announcements of the original iPhone in 2007 and the iPad in 2010. It would have been an extreme disappointment if the event ended without the announcement of a new product category.

Of course, everyone figured it would be a watch, but just like the previous announcements in 2007 and 2010, no one had any idea what it would look like or what it would do. Apple is very good at secrecy when mass manufacturing for a product hasn't yet commenced, or when the product includes new software (as evidenced by the surprise announcement of the Swift programming language in June). Both were true in case. Prior to the announcement, the  Watch, as it is now known, had been produced in only limited test quantities, and the new version of iOS that it runs had never before been seen publicly.

The  Watch was announced in the context of the prior announcement of HealthKit in June. Special emphasis has been placed on the health and fitness features of the watch, with Apple going as far as producing a separate promotional video highlighting this use.

That said, the expectations for what this watch would do for health and fitness bordered on magical. Sources as reliable as the Wall Street Journal predicted that the device would " include up to 10 sensors." With current technology, I couldn't imagine how that many high-quality sensors could be included in a 1st generation product while still maintaining a reasonable size, cost and battery life. Sure enough, the actual product was more firmly grounded in reality, with just a single medical sensor to measure pulse, in addition to the activity tracking of the M8 chip and the new barometric functionality to measure elevation.

It's quite likely that these rumors have some basis in fact, however. The  Watch is the most intimate product ever created by Apple, and I'm not just referring to the ability to share your heartbeat with that special someone. It's a device that is in constant contact with your skin. Just that fact alone opens the door for many sensors beyond simple measurement of heart rate. In fact, I'd wager that the  Watch could open the floodgates to R&D into transcutaneous sensors, with the potential to transform how we see ourselves. The quantified self has just gotten much closer to reality.

So what can the  Watch do for healthcare right now? At the very least, the profile of wearable electronics will get a huge boost in the consumer sector. They will become more socially acceptable, and users will come to rely on them and even trust them to make meaningful differences in their lives. Laying this foundation now will be critical to encourage the adoption of more advanced wearable sensors in future devices.

How useful the watch ends up being for consumer health and fitness will ultimately come down to the combination of hardware and software. The fact that all of this data will be saved to HealthKit is very attractive, because the data can then be shared with any other HealthKit-enabled health or fitness app the user chooses. Giving this power to the user is a smart move, and will likely foster a more open and diverse ecosystem of useful health and fitness apps moving forward.

With respect to use of the  Watch in the clinical setting, I love learning about and using new technology, but I’m also cognizant that the modern reality of electronic medical records has resulted in tension within the physician-patient relationship. During a typical visit, physicians often find themselves staring at a computer screen rather than interacting with the patient.

In medical school we were taught the Latin phrase, “primum, non nocere” or, “first, do no harm.” When technology interferes with the relationship we have with our patients, harm is being done. When technology enhances our work while remaining transparent to the interaction, we can make progress. Technologies such as the  Watch have the potential to take us a step in that direction by providing another avenue for relatively unobtrusive data access. As a developer myself, I’m looking forward to the arrival of the WatchKit SDK so I can see more fully how this functionality might be integrated into our medical environment, both from the perspective of a user as well as a physician.

"When technology interferes with the relationship we have with our patients, harm is being done. When technology enhances our work while remaining transparent to the interaction, we can make progress."

How could the watch be improved? It'll be easier to see once the watch has been released and the limitations become more apparent. But for starters, the watch needs to be waterproof. While there's no official statement on this, David Pogue revealed that it's likely just water resistant. I'm an avid swimmer, and one of the reasons I love my Pebble Smartwatch is because I never have to take it off (plus, it lasts up to 5-7 days per charge). This would be critical for any users whose primary form of physical activity involves water sports. Many of our patients who participate in cardiac rehab are often involved in water aerobics, and they would have to remove the watch to participate, thus nullifying much of the activity tracking benefit.

Battery life also needs to be at least several days. I've heard some lamentations that the watch doesn't have sleep tracking functionality like some of the other popular wearables. If the  Watch has a battery life of only 24 hours as rumored, sleep tracking would be an impossibility given that the watch would need to charged at night, every night. The watch also appears a bit too bulky in its current iteration to keep on while sleeping (in my opinion).

I'm confident all these issues will be resolved over time in future iterations of the watch (or competing watches). Progress will continue and app developers will surely come up with uses that Apple hasn't even considered. Mobile health innovators should pay close attention to this new product category. It will eventually revolutionize how we care for our patients and ourselves.

This article was originally posted on Ricky Bloomfield's blog. Dr. Bloomfield is the Director of Mobile Technology Strategy as well as Assistant Professor in Internal Medicine & Pediatrics at Duke University. He is passionate about the integration of meaningful mobile technologies into healthcare to improve the health of those around us.

To read other insights from our own mobile developers, check out more mobile ideas on our blog,
summary: As a hospitalist at Duke University who takes care of both children and adults, as well as the Director of Mobile Technology Strategy, I get to take care of patients both one at a time as well as a million at a time. Technology has never held so much promise for the improvement of medical care as it does right now. These are my thoughts on how we can make that happen.
title:  Watch - Relevant to Healthcare?
